==Europe== Advertising company [[JCDecaux]] launched its ''"Cyclocity"'' programs initially in [[:de:Citybike Wien|Vienna]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Supplying Self Service Bikes|url=http://www.jcdecaux.com/partners/supplying-self-service-bikes|website=JCDecaux|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> Austria in 2003 and in [[Vélo'v|Lyon]], France in 2005. The company also started programs in other cities in Europe such as [[Velib|Paris]], [[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]], and [[Kazan]], as well as cities outside of Europe, such as [[Brisbane]], Australia. Payment for using the bikes is done with [[smart card]]s.
Competitor [[Clear Channel]], then operating as Adshel, opened the first example of this in Rennes in 1997, and has several other sites including [[Oslo Bysykkel|Oslo]], Stockholm, [[Sandnes]] and [[Trondheim]], most generally similar to that offered by their competitor.
A different financial model called [[bicing]] is used in [[Barcelona]], which is paid for by car owners parking on public streets and not by advertising – which is contracted to JCDecaux in some places.<ref>[http://www.adshel.com/content.aspx?ID=31&ParentID=27&MicrositeID=0&Page=1 Adshel<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117011636/http://www.adshel.com/content.aspx?ID=31&ParentID=27&MicrositeID=0&Page=1 |date=17 January 2013 }}</ref>
===Austria=== In 2001, the city of [[Vienna]] implemented a first version of a bike sharing system following the example of Copenhagen. Unfortunately, ''Viennabike'' failed and its shortcomings were fixed in the second implementation called [[:de:Citybike Wien|Citybike Wien]], which started 2003. It is operated by [[:de:Gewista|Gewista]] and comprises 1500 bikes distributed to 121 stations with 3097 slots.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://citybikewien.at/en/about-citybike/press/143-2015-year-in-review|title=2015 Year in Review|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|accessdate=1 August 2016|author=Citybike Wien}}</ref> In 2015, more than 1 million trips and more than 100,000 new registrations were recorded. There is no fee for the first rental hour, additional hours are charged starting with €1.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://citybikewien.at/en/fees|title=Fees – Citybike Wien|website=citybikewien.at|access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref>
===Belgium=== [[File:VilloStationAlmostFull.jpg|thumb|Line of bikes at a Villo! station]] The [[Villo!]] system was launched in Brussels in 2009, and is operated by JCDecaux. It's the company's second biggest [[JCDecaux#Bicycle Rental Systems|bicycle rental system]] after Paris in terms of quantity.{{clarify|quantity of what? Bikes? Stations? Hires?|date=February 2017}} At the beginning of April 2015, it had 4115 bikes across 346 stations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Villo! bike sharing relieves public transport in Brussels (Belgium)|url=http://www.eltis.org/discover/case-studies/villo-bike-sharing-relieves-public-transport-brussels-belgium|accessdate=14 July 2016|publisher=Eltis|date=29 August 2014}}</ref>
In [[Antwerp]], a bike system called Velo went public in 2011. It is operated by [[Clear Channel]] and registered {{val|2558657}} journeys in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.velo-antwerpen.be/nl/blog/velo-antwerpen-in-cijfers |title=VELO ANTWERPEN IN CIJFERS |author=Velo Antwerpen |date=27 August 2014 |website=Velo Antwerpen |access-date=5 April 2014}}</ref>
===Bulgaria=== [[Burgas]] is the first Bulgarian city to introduce a public rent-a-bike system. The scheme is called VeloBurgas and has 10 access points with 120 bikes in operation. The rent-a-bike system works with cards, SMS, and POS. Prices range from 0.50 to 1 lev per hour.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gotoburgas.com/en/index/static/31 |title=Go To Burgas: Cycling |author=Go To Burgas |date=5 November 2015 |website=Go To Burgas |access-date=1 December 2015}}</ref>
===Cyprus=== [[File:New Public Buses in Nicosia Republic of Cyprus in the afternoon.jpg|thumb|Public bicycles in [[Nicosia]], Cyprus]] Bike in Action operates in the greater Nicosia area, similar to programmes employed in various cities of Cyprus. Bicycles can be found at stations in all participating municipalities (Agios Dometios, [[Aglandjia]], Dali, Engomi, Latsia, Pallouriotissa, [[Strovolos]]) and returned after their use at any station. Bike in Action includes more than 310 bikes distributed in 27 full automated [[Smoove]] stations, which cover the wide Nicosia area. All the rental stations are connected with the banking system and access to the bikes can be obtained with the use of a credit card.<ref name="Η Λευκωσία καλωσόρισε έναν νέο, υγιεινό τρόπο μετακίνησης στην πόλη">{{cite web|url=http://bike-sharing-gr.blogspot.com/search/label/%CE%94%CE%95%CE%A0%CE%9B%7ctitle=BikeSharing.gr%7cwork=bike-sharing-gr.blogspot.com|title=ένα blog για τα Συστήματα Αυτόματης Μίσθωσης Ποδηλάτων ...και οτιδήποτε αφορά το Ποδήλατο! ''a blog for Bicycle Sharing Systems ... and everything about Bicycles!''|publisher=BikeSharing.gr}}</ref>
=== Czech Republic === <br /> [[File:Rekola NTK.jpg|thumb|[[Rekola]] bikes in [[Prague]], Czech Republic]] The most widespread bike sharing system is called [[Rekola]]. It started operating in Prague in 2013. In 2018, it was operating in 8 Czech cities (Prague, [[Brno]], [[Ostrava]], [[České Budějovice]], [[Liberec]], [[Frýdek-Místek]], [[Teplice]] and [[Olomouc]]) with more than 1000 pink bikes. There are also two smaller providers in Prague: HomePort<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prahakola.cz/|title=Homeport - systém automatické půjčovny kol|last=|first=|date=|website=Český bikesharing v Praze|language=cs|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-12-01}}</ref> with docking stations in [[Karlín]] district and Velonet in [[Prague 4]] and Brno.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://praha.velonet.cz/|title=Velonet Praha|website=praha.velonet.cz|language=en|access-date=2018-12-01}}</ref>
===Denmark=== Following earlier bike-sharing systems, Denmark introduced the first ''next generation'' bike-sharing system in 1991 in [[Farsø]].<ref name="velo2009">{{citation | first = Paul | last = DeMaio | contribution = Bike‐sharing: Its History, Models of Provision, and Future | title = Velo‐city 2009 Conference | publisher = MetroBike, LLC | place = Washington, D.C. | date = May 2009 | contribution-url = http://www.velo-city2009.com/assets/files/paper-DeMaio-Bike%20sharing-sub5.2.pdf | chapter-format = PDF | accessdate = 2012-11-01}}</ref> This small-scale scheme paved the way for the [[Copenhagen City Bikes|Copenhagen's ''ByCyklen'']] programme, which was introduced in 1995 and was the first large-scale urban bike-sharing programme to feature specially designed bicycles with parts which could not be used on other bikes. Riders paid a refundable deposit at one of 110 special locking bike stands, and the riders then had unlimited use of the bike within a specified 'city bike zone'.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The fine for not returning a bicycle or leaving the bike-sharing zone was strictly enforced by [[Police of Denmark|the police]]. The founders hoped to completely finance the programme by selling advertising space on the bicycles. This funding source quickly proved to be insufficient, and the city of Copenhagen took over the administration of the programme, funding most of the programme costs through appropriations from city revenues. Since it was free to the user, there is no return on the capital invested by the municipality, and a considerable amount of public funds was constantly used to keep the system in service. In 2013 a new version was expected to be introduced but the municipality of Copenhagen temporarily withdrew its support and there were no free bicycles for most of 2013.<ref name="goby">{{cite web |url= http://www.copenhagenize.com/2012/10/goodbye-bycyklen.html |title=Goodbye Bycyklen |first=Mikael |last=Colville-Andersen |work=copenhagenize.com |date=31 October 2012 |accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="17aar">{{cite news | first = Malacinski | last = Leny | title = Bycyklen afgår ved døden, 17 år gammel | date = 1 November 2012 | work = [[Jyllands-Posten]] | page = 10}}</ref><ref name="svigt">{{cite news | first = Rytter | last = Niels | author2=Flemming Christiansen | title = Kritik: Kommunen svigtede bycyklen | date = 31 October 2012 | work = [[Politiken]] | language = Danish}}</ref> Copenhagen municipality changed its mind and a new version was introduced in late 2013.<ref>[https://archive.is/20140623044859/http://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/nyhedsliste/2013/3-kvartal/tmf-bycykel Verdenspremiere på Frederiksberg og Københavns nye, intelligente bycykler] About Bycyklen in Copenhagen. Accessed 9 November 2018</ref>
[[Copenhagen]] was among the first cities in the world to have a free bike scheme called ''[[Copenhagen City Bikes|City Bikes]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=BICYCLE CULTURE|url=http://denmark.dk/en/green-living/bicycle-culture/|website=The Official Website of Denmark|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> which was paid by advertising on the bikes.
In late 2013, Copenhagen started a new program with electric bikes. The first phase of this program, with 1860 bikes and 105 docking stations, is to be completed in early 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bach |first1=Ursula |title=The New Bike Share System is a Perfect Fit for Copenhagen |url=http://gobike.com/cities/denmark/copenhagen-1/ |accessdate=1 December 2015 |publisher=Go Bike |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208135042/http://gobike.com/cities/denmark/copenhagen-1/ |archivedate=8 December 2015 }}</ref>
===Finland=== [[File:Helsinki city bikes.jpg|thumb|Old defunct (2000 - 2010) [[Helsinki]] city bikes]] [[Helsinki City Bikes|City Bikes scheme]] in Helsinki launched in 2016, run by Helsinki City Transport (HKL), in collaboration with Moventia and Smoove. In the summer of 2017, City Bikes had 1500 bikes in 150 locations.<ref>{{cite web | title = Bike-share returns to Helsinki in 2016 | publisher = [[Yle]] | url = http://yle.fi/uutiset/bike-share_returns_to_helsinki_in_2016/8385342 | accessdate = 16 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Helsinki's city bike procurement process evaluates usability | publisher = Design Driven City | url = http://www.toimivakaupunki.fi/en/news/helsinkis-city-bike-procurement-process-evaluates-usability/ | accessdate = 16 January 2017 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170305025425/http://www.toimivakaupunki.fi/en/news/helsinkis-city-bike-procurement-process-evaluates-usability/ | archivedate = 5 March 2017 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Espoossa ja Vantaalla hamutaan kaupunkipyöriä – "Ei yhtään pöllömpi idea" | publisher = [[Helsingin Sanomat]] |language=Finnish| url = http://www.hs.fi/kaupunki/a1464066196956 | accessdate = 16 January 2017 }}</ref>
===France=== [[File:Vélo'v station 5002 - Place des Compagnons de la chanson.jpg|thumb|[[Vélo'v]] in [[Lyon]]]] [[File:Velibvelo1.jpg|thumb|[[Velib']] bicycle station in Paris]] In 1974, the French city of [[La Rochelle]] launched a free bike-sharing programme, [[Vélos Jaunes]] (Yellow Bikes), featuring unisex bicycles which were free to take and use. In terms of public usage and acceptance, it is regarded today as one of the first truly successful bike-sharing programmes. The programme continues today, albeit in modified form (rental charges apply after the first two hours, and personal identification is required for all bike rentals).
[[File:Place de la République (Paris), réaménagement, 2012-04-05 39.jpg|thumb|The [[Vélib']] in Paris is the largest system outside China{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}]] French cities offering a bicycle sharing system include [[Marseille]], [[Lyon]], [[Bordeaux]], [[Nice]], [[Toulouse]], [[Rennes]], [[Rouen]], [[La Rochelle]], [[Orléans]], [[Montpellier]], [[Nantes]], [[Lille]], [[Dunkirk]], [[Strasbourg]], Clermont-Ferrand, Avignon, Saint-Étienne, Chalon sur Saône, Belfort, Lorient, Annemasse, Valence, and Aix-en-Provence.
The launch of [[Velo'v]] in [[Lyon]], France in 2005 was an effort to improve on the disappointing performance of the traditional municipal public bike-sharing model. In an attempt to improve upon the results of the discontinued ''Bikeabout'' program at the University of Portsmouth, ''Velo'v'' utilised "smart" technology to reduce theft, user damage, and vandalism. Considered to be a city less than friendly to cyclists prior to 2005, the ''Velo'v'' programme is credited with stimulating an increase of 500% in bicycle trips within the city, a quarter of which used the bike sharing system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metrobike.net/index.php?s=file_download&id=16 |title="The Bike-sharing Phenomenon – The History of Bike-sharing", Paul DeMaio |accessdate=15 January 2012}}</ref><ref>''[[Carbusters]]'' magazine No. 36, November 2008</ref>
A resurgence in bike sharing programmes is attributed by many to the launching in 2007 of Paris's [[Vélib']], a network of 18,000 specially designed bicycles distributed among 1,230 stations throughout Paris. Vélib', inspired by Lyon's seminal ''Vélo'v'' project, is now considered the second largest bike-sharing system of its kind in the world. 80 percent of Vélib's original 20,600 bicycles have been destroyed or stolen.<ref>Erlanger, Steven and De La Baume, Maïa, ''French Ideal of Bicycle-Sharing Meets Reality'', The New York Times, 30 October 2009</ref> Some Vélib' cycles have been found in Eastern Europe and North Africa, while others have been dumped in the [[Seine]] River, hung from lampposts, or abandoned on the roadside in various states of disrepair, forcing the City of Paris to reimburse the programme operator an estimated $2 million per year for excess costs under its contractual agreement.<ref>Erlanger, Steven and De La Baume, Maia, ''French Ideal of Bicycle-Sharing Meets Reality'', The New York Times, 30 October 2009</ref>
===Germany=== Germany has bike-sharing programmes in many cities, including [[Aachen]], [[Berlin]], [[Cologne]], [[Düsseldorf]], [[Frankfurt]], [[Hamburg]] (StadtRAD Hamburg), [[Karlsruhe]], [[Kassel]] (Konrad), [[Mainz]] (MVGmeinRad), [[Munich]] and [[Stuttgart]]. The station-based system Metropolradruhr is located in the [[Ruhr Area]]. Bike-sharing stations are also located in over 50 ICE railway stations.<ref>[http://www.eturbonews.com/31673/germany-ranks-third-globally-quality-infrastructure "Germany ranks third globally for quality infrastructure – eTurboNews.com"] "For those that prefer exercise and the ultimate green way to get around on two wheels, Germany even features the "Call a Bike" program in eight cities and at over 40 train stations."</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.callabike-interaktiv.de/index.php?id=401& |title=Call a Bike: Überblick |work=callabike-interaktiv.de |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826231125/https://www.callabike-interaktiv.de/index.php?id=401& |archivedate=26 August 2014 }}</ref>
===Greece=== In November 2010, [[Corfu (city)|Corfu]] launched EasyBike, which includes one hundred bicycles that are distributed in eight rental stations throughout the town. The method of operation is similar to other such systems in Europe. Residents can obtain a special electronic subscriber card from the Municipality, which gives them access to bicycles and occasional users can use their credit card to rent a bicycle.<ref name="Ορθοπεταλιές ενάντια στη ρύπανση και την ακρίβεια">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsbeast.gr/society/arthro/80388/orthopetalies-enadia-sti-rupansi-kai-tin-akriveia|title=ΚΟΙΝΩΝΙΑ : Ορθοπεταλιές ενάντια στη ρύπανση και την ακρίβεια ''SOCIETY: Orthopedics against pollution and precision''|work=newsbeast.gr}}</ref> The system also gives users the ability to obtain a code and gain access to bicycles through an IVR automated system by using their credit card. EasyBike bike sharing system is developed by Brainbox under a [[Smoove]] license, which is the first Greek company to implement a bike sharing project in Greece.<ref name="Κέρκυρα: Σύστημα αυτόματης ενοικίασης ποδηλάτων">[http://www.naftemporiki.gr/localnews/story.asp?id=1901990 Κέρκυρα: Σύστημα αυτόματης ενοικίασης ποδηλάτων ''Corfu: Bicycle rental system'']{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
There are also other programmes similar to bicycle sharing systems, which are not automated. The first, running from early 2010, is in the northern suburb of [[Nea Erithréa, Greece|Nea Erithréa]], in [[Attica]], while the second is that of the [[Nafpaktos|Municipality of Nafpaktos]], which has been in operation since mid June 2010. In these programmes, the residents rent the bike directly from the municipality. In the programme implemented in Nea Erithréa, bicycles are rented for one week to six months, on condition that the user must submit to the municipality 75 euros as a guarantee. In Nafpaktos, bicycles are rented for up to two months for free.<ref name="Ενοικιαζόμενες ορθοπεταλιές">{{cite web|url=http://www.tanea.gr/default.asp?pid=2&ct=1&artid=4592683|title=Ενοικιαζόμενες ορθοπεταλιές ''(The Municipalities of Eritrea, Corfu and Nafpaktos rent bikes to their citizens)''|author=Τα Νέα Οnline|date=6 September 2010|work=Τα Νέα Οnline}}</ref> In 2011, the [[Iraklio|municipality of Heraklion]] in Crete purchased 100 bicycles from the bike-sharing company Brainbox, the developer of EasyBike<ref name="EasyBike στον Δήμο Ηρακλείου">{{cite web|url=http://www.easybike.gr/el/bikesharing-news/116-easybike-dimos-irakleiou-kritis |title=100 ποδήλατα EasyBike στον Δήμο Ηρακλείου ''100 EasyBike bikes in the Municipality of Heraklion''|author=George Voulgaroudis |work=easybike.gr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025202646/http://www.easybike.gr/el/bikesharing-news/116-easybike-dimos-irakleiou-kritis |archivedate=25 October 2014 }}</ref> system while free distribution of bicycles from the municipality had already started from April 2010.<ref name="Ηράκλειο">{{cite web|url=http://www.citybranding.gr/2010/04/blog-post_22.html|title=Ηράκλειο : Δωρεάν διάθεση ποδηλάτων για χρήση στη παραλιακή λεωφόρο : Πόλεις και Πολιτικές ''Heraklion: Free use of bicycles for use on the coastal avenue: Cities and Policies''|work=citybranding.gr}}</ref>
In May 2012, a non-automated system was introduced at the [[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]], in Salonica, Northern Greece. It presents 60 public bikes available for the University community. The system has no electronic rental stations and the delivery and return of the bikes is made by students working part-time on the project.<ref name="Το Πρώτο Σύστημα Κοινόχρηστων Ποδηλάτων στο Α.Π.Θ.">{{cite web|url=http://press.auth.gr/news/wordpress/?p=30696 |title=Το Πρώτο Σύστημα Κοινόχρηστων Ποδηλάτων στο Α.Π.Θ. ''The First Communal Cycle System at Aristotle University of Thessaloniki.''|publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510025646/http://press.auth.gr/news/wordpress/?p=30696 |archivedate=10 May 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===Hungary===
====Esztergom==== [[File:Esztergom - Ebi atadas 2013-09-20.jpg|thumb|The EBI in Esztergom, Hungary]] The first public bicycle sharing service in Hungary was implemented in [[Esztergom]] on 20 September 2013. The Esztergom Bicycle or EBI was developed by Neuzer, a local bicycle manufacturing company.<ref>[https://www.szeretgom.hu/content/73810-atadtak-az-ebi-t/ Átadták az EBI-t | Szeretgom.hu] 20 September 2013.</ref>
====Szeged==== The country's second bike sharing system in [[Szeged]] is CityBike Szeged. It has been in operation since 1 October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citybikeszeged.hu/en|title=CityBike|work=citybikeszeged.hu|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delmagyar.hu/szeged_hirek/jovo_heten_indul_a_citybike/2352402/|title=Jövő héten indul a Citybike ''Next week will be Citybike''|work=delmagyar.hu}}</ref>
====Győr==== GyőrBike opened on 7 September 2015 in [[Győr]] with 23 docks and 180 bicycles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hg.hu/cikkek/varos/17136-itt-a-gyorbike-gyorben-is-elindult-a-kozbringa|title=Itt a GyőrBike: Győrben is elindult a közbringa! ''Here is the GyőrBike: Gyor has started the race!''|work=HG.HU – Design meets Life}}</ref>
====Kaposvár==== The Kaposvári Tekergő opened on 27 October 2015 in [[Kaposvár]] with 4 docking stations, 26 e-bikes and 6 e-rollers.<ref name="kaposvarmost.hu">{{cite web|url=https://kaposvarmost.hu/videok/kaposvar-most/2015/10/27/matol-barki-hasznalhatja-a-kozbiciklit.html |title=Mától bárki használhatja a közbiciklit ''From now on anyone can use the public bicycle''|publisher=}}</ref>
====Budapest==== [[File:BuBi bicycles in a docking station..jpg|thumb|[[BuBi]] in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]]]] [[Budapest]] has the largest bicycle sharing system in [[Hungary]]. Operated jointly by [[Budapesti Közlekedési Központ|BKK]] and [[MOL Group|MOL]], the [[BuBi]] system was launched in September 2014<ref>{{cite web |url=https://molbubi.bkk.hu/a-molbubi.php |title=MOL Bubi |language=en |accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> and has over 1500 bicycles and 120 docking stations as of November 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=Budapest Goes Greener: Take Advantage of the Car, Bike and Scooter-Sharing Boom |url=https://hungarytoday.hu/budapest-goes-greener-advantage-car-bike-scooter-sharing-boom/ |accessdate=14 November 2018 |work=Hungary Today |date=9 September 2018}}</ref>
===Ireland=== In September 2009, Dublin launched a bike-share scheme known as [[dublinbikes]] operated by JCDecaux. With an initial 450 bicycles, the plan reached 1 million uses in less than a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dublinbikes.ie/Magazine/News/One-million-journeys |title=One million journeys / News / Magazine / Dublin – Dublinbikes |publisher=Dublinbikes.ie |accessdate=15 January 2012}}</ref> As of June 2013, the scheme has had fewer than 12 bikes stolen or damaged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/twowheel-triumph-fewer-than-12-free-dublin-bikes-stolen-in-four-years-29327917.html|title=Two-wheel triumph: Fewer than 12 free Dublin Bikes stolen in four years|accessdate=19 June 2013 | work=Irish Independent}}</ref>
===Italy=== [[File:Bike share.jpg|thumb|[[BikeMi]], Milan, Italy]] [[Milan]] has the largest bike sharing system in Italy, [[BikeMi]], which was launched on 8 December 2008. It is contracted to and operated by [[Clear Channel]] on the basis of its SmartBike system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://smartbike.com/article_view?a3063 |title=Clear Channel Jolly launches BikeMi |publisher=smartbike.com |date=8 December 2008 |accessdate=17 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110922193855/http://www.smartbike.com/article_view?a3063 |archivedate=22 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The scheme encompasses 4,650 bicycles, which includes 1,000 electric bicycles and bikes for children.<ref name=mar14>{{cite news|title=Il bike sharing punta ai 50 mila|url=https://www.bikemi.com/media/106456/10_Repubblica.pdf|accessdate=18 March 2014|newspaper=la Repubblica|date=10 March 2014}}</ref> and 280 stations.<ref>[https://www.bikemi.com/it/media/eventi-news/news.aspx#giovedi-31-marzo-bikemi-inaugura-la-280-stazione-1 giovedi 31 marzo: bikemi inaugura la 280 stazione] ''bikemi.com/it/media/eventi-news'' accessed 31 October 2018</ref> Another large system exists in [[Turin]]. Since 2017, Mobike and OFO dockless systems also operate in Milan and Florence.<ref>[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2017-07/26/content_30250271.htm Mobike expands in Europe with Italian bike-sharing] at chinadaily.com.cn, accessed 8 April 2018</ref> Several other cities, especially in the north, have smaller bike sharing systems.<ref name="Demm">{{cite web|last1=SAIBENE|first1=GIORGIO|last2=MANZ|first2=GIANCARLO|title=Bike Usage In Public Bike-Sharing: An Analysis Of The "BikeMe" System in Milan|url=http://wp.demm.unimi.it/files/wp/2015/DEMM-2015_01wp.pdf|website=Demm|publisher=Universita Degli Studi Di Milano|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref>
===Netherlands=== In 1965, the group [[Provo (movement)|Provo]] painted fifty bicycles white and scattered them unlocked in downtown [[Amsterdam]] for everyone to use freely.<ref name="Larsen"/> The bicycles were both taken by people, and impounded by the authorities, as a city ordinance forbade leaving unlocked bikes in public places.<ref>{{cite web|title=How bike-sharing conquered the world|url=https://www.economist.com/news/christmas-specials/21732701-two-wheeled-journey-anarchist-provocation-high-stakes-capitalism-how|website=The Economist|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Zee|first1=Renate van der|title=Story of cities #30: how this Amsterdam inventor gave bike-sharing to the world|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/apr/26/story-cities-amsterdam-bike-share-scheme|website=The Guardian|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=26 April 2016}}</ref>
In September 1997, a pilot project for a public share system, based on the UK's ''Grippa'' racks was established in [[Rotterdam]], for use by commuters, but it was terminated the following year due to poor functionality of the electronic bike racks.<ref name="DeM"/> [[File:OV-fiets recycle Spoorparade.jpg|thumb|The Netherlands: OV-fiets]]
The Netherlands has a single nationwide bike sharing program, called "OV-fiets", which means 'public transport bike'.<ref>"Cycling in the Netherlands"(PDF)(page 48). Rijkswaterstaat (Dutch Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management)</ref> The system has 8500 bikes in 252 locations, mainly train stations, all over the country. Membership is required (annual fee €0.01, €3.85 per rental day) and can be combined with an [[OV-chipkaart]]. The program, which started on a small scale in 2003, has enjoyed a steadily increasing popularity with over 1.53 million rides registered in 2014. The nature of the Dutch bike sharing program differs from that of programs in other countries partly because the already high bike ownership of the population. Its interconnection with the public transport network allows it to fill the need of people who also want to continue traveling by bike from the station of their destination.<ref>{{cite web|title=Annual Report 2014|url=http://www.nsjaarverslag.nl/FbContent.ashx/pub_1000/downloads/annual-report-2014.pdf|website=Bouwen aanaantrekkelijk OV|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
===Norway=== The first Norwegian bicycle sharing system was introduced in [[Sandnes]]<ref>[http://www.visitnorway.com/no/Product/?pid=31688 Bysykkel i Sandnes ''City bike in Sandnes''] at visitnorway.com, accessed 8 April 2018</ref> in 1996.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|last1=Langfeldt|first1=Tuva|title=BYSYKLER perspektiver på bysykkelordninger som en del av en bærekraftig bytransport og urban identitet|url=https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/52080501.pdf|website=core.ac.uk|publisher=UNIVERSITETET FOR MILJØ|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> It consisted of 225 green DBS bikes that were free to use in the fashion of a 1st generation bicycle sharing system. The Sandnes system was converted to a 3rd generation system in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandnes var pilotby|url=http://www.sørfylket.no/nyheter/sandnes/2485-sandnes-var-pilotby.htm|website=sørfylket.no|publisher=SØRFYLKET.no|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> In 1998, Trondheim introduced a 2nd generation system with 200 bicycles modeled after that of Copenhagen's. The Trondheim system was converted into a 3rd generation system in 2005. The following cities are known to have city bike arrangements. Some are prepaid automatic (example Oslo), some are manual (like in Tønsberg). In 2001, [[Drammen]] introduced a 3rd generation system together with the Clear Channel.<ref name="auto"/> *[[Drammen]] *[[Oslo]] - [[Oslo Bysykkel]] (172 rental hubs as of March 2017<ref>[https://www.abcnyheter.no/penger/naeringsliv/2017/10/08/195337726/punktering-bysykkelordning-i-oslo Punktering for bysykkelordning i Oslo ''Puncture for city cycling in Oslo''] at abcnyheter.no, accessed 8 April 2018</ref>) *[[Sandnes]] *[[Trondheim]] *[[Tønsberg]]
===Poland=== The first bike-sharing program was launched in Kraków (Cracow) on 16 September 2008. As of 2016, 12 cities and towns in Poland have bike-sharing programs, most of them operated by [[nextbike]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nextbike.pl/en|title=Nextbike – system rowerów miejskich|publisher=}}</ref>
===Portugal=== Portugal has 13 bike-sharing programs functioning year-round as of October 2016, namely in the cities of [http://www.ciclovia.pt/albiclas.html Águeda] (1 station/ 10 pedelecs), [http://www.cm-anadia.pt/b-and/ Anadia] (10 stations), [http://www.ciclovia.pt/albiclas.html Aveiro] (33 stations/350 bicycles), [https://www.mobicascais.com/rede-mobi/cat/cat_1 Cascais] (October 2017: 19 stations inaugurated; 120 stations and 1200 bicycles by December, 2017), [https://www.gira-bicicletasdelisboa.pt/ Lisbon] (October, 2017: 10 stations inaugurated/100 bicycles; 140 stations and 1410 bicycles by December, 2017 of which 920 will be pedelecs), [https://www.cm-oaz.pt/noticias.6/concelho.14/.a5310.html Oliveira de Azemeis] (3 stations/20 pedelecs), [http://www.ciclovia.pt/albiclas.html Ovar] (12 stations/130 bicycles), [http://www.ciclovia.pt/albiclas.html#BIPParedes Paredes] (5 stations/80 bicycles), [http://biks.cm-santarem.pt/ Santarém] (4 stations/40 bicycles), [http://www.cm-serpa.pt/bicicard/ Serpa] (2 stations/30 bicycles), [http://www.cm-tvedras.pt/mobilidade/agostinhas/ Torres Vedras] (11 stations/260 bicycles), [http://www.inframoura.pt/pt/vilamoura-public-bikes Vilamoura] (32 stations/200 bicycles), and [http://www.cm-viladoconde.pt/pages/344 Vila do Conde] (12 stations/60 bicycles).
===Romania=== [[Timișoara]] is the first Romanian city to introduce a public rent-a-bike system. The scheme is called VeloTM and has 25 stations and 300 bikes. The rent-a-bike system works with the [[Regia Autonomă de Transport Timișoara|RATT]] card. Renting a bike is free however, the card costs.<ref>{{cite web|title=VeloTM|url=http://www.velotm.ro/|accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
===The Russian Federation=== [[File:Velobike in Moscow 01.jpg|thumb|VeloBike bicycles in Moscow]] Automated public bicycle sharing services in Russia operate in Moscow, [[Sankt-Petersburg]], and [[Kazan]].
On 1 July 2013, the [[Bank of Moscow]] started the system called [[Velobike]], which was replaced in 2014 by [[Smoove]]-based solution using [[B'Twin|B’TWIN]] bicycles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyclehop.com/moscow-launches-velobike-with-smoove-bike-share-equipment/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140615101734/http://cyclehop.com/moscow-launches-velobike-with-smoove-bike-share-equipment/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2014 |title=Moscow Launches VeloBike with Smoove Bike Share Equipment |accessdate=14 June 2014 |publisher=Cyclehop }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=SHARED CYCLING BOOMS IN RUSSIA|url=http://www.thinkrussia.com/business-economy/shared-cycling-booms-russia|accessdate=17 June 2016|publisher=Think Russia|date=31 July 2014}}</ref> The VeloBike program has 2500 bicycles and 150 stations. It is sponsored by the Bank of Moscow and Sberbank of Russia. It is compatible with ''Troika'', the Moscow public transportation system and accessible to occasional users as well.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/moscow-lifehack-how-do-i-use-moscow-city-bikes-53118 |title=Moscow Lifehack: How Do I Use Moscow City Bikes? |date=6 June 2016 |work=The Moscow Times |publisher=The Moscow Times}}</ref>
===Slovakia=== In 2001, the not-for-profit organization ''BiCyBa'' released ''White Bicycles'' into public use in Bratislava, Slovakia. During the next three months all the bikes were stolen or destroyed, and the project was cancelled.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bratislava.sme.sk/c/20242842/v-meste-je-stovka-verejnych-bicyklov-ako-sa-k-nim-dostat.html |title=''There are hundreds of public bicycles in the city. How do you access them?''|date=2016 August 19 |website=bratislava.sme.sk |language=sk-SK|accessdate=2018-12-03</ref><ref> http://bratislava.sme.sk/c/124828/biele-bicykle-v-centre-stroskotali.html Biele bicykle v centre stroskotali' 6 October 2001</ref> In 2013, a new community-run bike-sharing program in [[Bratislava]] called White Bikes commenced service with about 100 bikes (donated by local Rotary Club<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cyklokoalicia.sk/biele-bicykle/|title=Čo sú to Biele bicykle? ''(What are White Bikes?)''|date=2015-05-07|work=Cyklokoalícia|access-date=2017-12-31|language=sk-SK}}</ref>) and over 60 stations (as of December 2017).<ref>[http://whitebikes.info Bratislava scheme at whitebikes.info] Accessed 14 June 2017</ref> It is built on the ''Open Source Bike Share System''<ref>[http://opensourcebikeshare.com ''Free bike sharing system suitable for smaller communities, university campuses, companies. Launch your own!'' at opensourcebikeshare.com] Accessed 14 June 2017</ref> based on an SMS and a web app. It was started in 2013 by BikeKitchen initiative and cycling advocacy NGO ''Cyklokoalicia''. There is no fee to use bikes, membership is granted after initial personal introduction and training. Bikes are available all year long.
Official [[Bratislava]] city bike sharing [[Slovnaft Bajk]] was launched on September 7, 2018<ref>[https://dennikn.sk/1235844/bicyklov-je-v-bratislave-denne-asi-200-problemy-riesime-hovori-szabo-zo-slovnaftu/ Matej Dugovic, 19 september 2018: Bicyklov je v Bratislave denne asi 200, problémy riešime, hovorí Szabó zo Slovnaftu] ''dennikn.sk'', accessed 31 October 2018</ref> in cooperation with Slovnaft company. It offered only under 100 bicycles initially at around 80 stations (based on the [https://slovnaftbajk.cyklokoalicia.sk/public/ public stats]). Number of bicycles increased to around 190 later, but users complained about the UX and broken bicycles / rental process. Estimated 23%<ref>{{cite web |last1=Netri |first1=Peter |title=Koľko je skutočne SlovnaftBAjkov a dajú sa požičať? |url=https://cyklokoalicia.sk/2018/10/kolko-je-skutocne-slovnaftbajkov-a-daju-sa-pozicat/ |title=There are hundreds of public bicycles in the city. How do you access them? |date=2016-08-16|website=Cyklokoalícia |accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> of bicycles were not working or rendered inaccessible for rental.
The first commercial bike sharing in Slovakia was launched in 2016 in the city of [[Prievidza]]. Zelený bicykel (translates as Green bicycle) has 19 stations and is expected to add 10 more in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.zelenybicykel.sk/2017/12/04/sezona-2017-ukoncena/|title=Sezóna 2017 ukončená (zhrnutie) ''(Season 2017 closed (summary))'' |website=blog.zelenybicykel.sk|language=sk-SK|access-date=2017-12-31}}</ref> Bikes are not available during winter season.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.zelenybicykel.sk/2017/11/28/odzvonilo/|title=Odzvonilo – ''(Green Bike- It's ringing)''|website=blog.zelenybicykel.sk|language=sk-SK|access-date=2017-12-31}}</ref>
Public transportation company [[Arriva]] launched a bike sharing in [[Nitra]] in 2017. It is a complementary service for its bus service. It only features 7 docking stations, the price is €25 per year, €3 per day or €0.50 per hour.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://eautoportal.sk/bike-sharing-nitra/|title=V Nitre spustili službu zdieľania bicyklov. K dispozícii je 70 bicyklov ''(In Nitra they launched a bicycle sharing service. There are 70 bicycles availabl. There are 70 Bikes available.)''|date=2017-08-17|work=eAutoPortal.sk|access-date=2017-12-31|language=sk-SK}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cyklokoalicia.sk/2017/09/bicykle-pod-zoborom/|title=Bicykle pod Zoborom ''(Bicycles under the Zobor)''|date=2017-09-18|work=Cyklokoalícia|access-date=2017-12-31|language=sk-SK}}</ref> Bikes are not available during winter season.
===Spain=== [[File:Estacio bicing bcn.jpg|thumb|[[Bicing]] in Barcelona]] The Ayuntamiento de Burgos<ref>[http://www.aytoburgos.es Ayuntamiento de Burgos] Accessed 14 June 2017</ref> runs a bike-sharing program in BiciBur,<ref name= BCB_ES>[http://BiciBur.es 'Tu Bici, tu Ciudad' ''(Your Bike, your City)''], at BiciBur.es, Accessed 14 June 2017</ref> with 23 locations, most with positions for ten bikes. Membership is €15 per year.<ref name= BCB_ES/>
===Sweden=== The [[Stockholm City Bikes]] system has more than 80 stands and 1,000 bikes, functioning from April to October.<ref>{{cite web|title="City Bikes" program lets you tour Stockholm on two wheels|url=http://www.eurocheapo.com/blog/stockholm-city-bikes-program.html|publisher=Euro Cheapo|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
The bike sharing system in Gothenburg, known as [[Styr & ställ]], was launched in August 2010. The system has 60 stations and 1,000 bikes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Making West Sweden Stronger |url=http://handelskammaren.net/en/articles/explore-gothenburg-by-bike/ |publisher=West Sweden Chamber of Commerce |accessdate=3 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309235520/http://handelskammaren.net/en/articles/explore-gothenburg-by-bike/ |archivedate=9 March 2016 }}</ref>
=== Switzerland === [[File:Web-5.jpg|thumb|A station in [[Lausanne]] (Switzerland).]]
Switzerland possesses several bicycle sharing systems including Publibike, Smide, and [[oBike]] which was launched in [[Zurich]] on 5 July 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Petrò|first1=Lorenzo|title=Plötzlich hat Zürich einen mobilen Veloverleih ''(Suddenly Zurich has a mobile bike rental)''|url=http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/zuerich/region/ploetzlich-hat-zuerich-einen-mobilen-veloverleih/story/24285267|accessdate=17 July 2017|publisher=Tages-Anzeiger|date= 14 July 2017}}</ref> The Publibike network consists of one hundred stations throughout the country.<ref>[https://www.publibike.ch/en/newsdetail---------1--18.html "A single card for 1000 bikes and e-bikes", at publibike.ch] (page visited on 23 June 2013).</ref> It includes nine stations on the [[Lausanne campus]].<ref>[https://www.publibike.ch/en/campus.html "Campus roule", at publibike.ch] (page visited on 23 June 2013).</ref> oBike is said to have deployed 350 bikes in the city of Zurich with bike hire being CHF 1.50 for 30 minutes, with a CHF 129 deposit being required.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Giusto|first1=Lina|title=O-Bike nutzt gewisse Orte übermässig ''(O-bike uses certain places excessively)''|url=https://www.limmattalerzeitung.ch/limmattal/zuerich/o-bike-nutzt-gewisse-orte-uebermaessig-131518995|accessdate=14 July 2017|publisher=Limmataler Zeitung|date= 17 July 2017}}</ref> The city of Zürich also has a free bike-rental program, "Züri rollt", with several pick-up and drop-off locations.<ref name="Zurich">{{cite web|title="Züri rollt" – Free Bicycle Rental in Zurich|url=https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/sport/zurich-on-wheels|website=Zurich on Wheels|publisher=Zurich on Wheels|accessdate=17 January 2017}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== ==== England ==== In 1993, a ''Green Bike Scheme'' bike sharing programme was initiated in [[Cambridge]], United Kingdom, using a fleet of some 300 bicycles. The overwhelming majority of the fleet were stolen or missing within a year of the programme's introduction, and the Green Bike Scheme was abandoned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article1717314.ece |title=Sailing through the lights, riding for a fall |28 Apr 2007, accessed 26 Nov 2008 |publisher=Timesonline.co.uk |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=2012-01-15 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Pilgrim Tom |url=https://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/cambridge-news/you-remember-cambridge-green-bike-12472055 |title=Do you remember the last time Cambridge had an 'Uber for bikes' scheme? |publisher=cambridge-news.co.uk |date=2018-01-18 |accessdate=2018-12-03 |location=Cambridge}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Elliott Chris |url=https://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/history/quirky-pedal-power-could-only-13096553 |title=Quirky pedal power that could only happen in Cambridge |publisher=cambridge-news.co.uk |date=2018-01-18 |accessdate=2018-12-03 |location=Cambridge}}</ref>
In an attempt to overcome losses from theft, the next innovation adopted by bike sharing programmes was the use of so-called '[[smart cards|smart technology]]'. One of the first 'smart bike' programmes was the ''Grippa™'' bike storage rack system used in [[Portsmouth]]'s ''Bikeabout'' scheme.<ref>[http://www.dixonbate.co.uk/cyclesecurity/velotron.asp Cycle Security – VeloTron] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321191612/http://www.dixonbate.co.uk/cyclesecurity/velotron.asp |date=21 March 2012 }}</ref><ref name="BLA">Black, Colin, Faber, Oscar, and Potter, Stephen, ''Portsmouth Bikeabout: A Smart-Card Bike Club Scheme'', The Open University (1998)</ref><ref name="DeM">{{cite journal |last1=DeMaio |first1=Paul |last2=Gifford |first2=Jonathan |title=Will Smart Bikes Succeed as Public Transportation in the United States? |journal=Journal of Public Transportation |volume=7 |issue=2 |year=2004 |pages=1–15 |doi=10.5038/2375-0901.7.2.1 }}</ref> The ''Bikeabout'' scheme was launched in October 1995 by the [[University of Portsmouth]], UK as part of its ''Green Transport Plan'' in an effort to cut car travel by staff and students between campus sites.<ref name="BLA" /> Funded in part by the EU's ENTRANCE<ref>Acronym for the ENergy savings in TRANsport through innovation in the Cities of Europe programme</ref> programme, the ''Bikeabout'' scheme was a "smart card" fully automated system.<ref name="BLA" /><ref name="DeM" /><ref name="REMCO">Hoogma, Remco, et al, ''Experimenting For Sustainable Transport: The approach of Strategic Niche Management'', London: Spon Press, {{ISBN|020399406X}} (2002), pp. 4–11, 176</ref> For a small fee, users were issued 'smart cards' with magnetic stripes to be swiped through an electronic card reader at a covered 'bike store' kiosk, unlocking the bike from its storage rack.<ref name="BLA" /> [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV camera]] surveillance was installed at all bike stations in an effort to limit vandalism.<ref name="BLA" /> Upon arriving at the destination station, the smart card was used to open a cycle rack and record the bike's safe return.<ref name="BLA" /> A charge was automatically registered on the user's card if the bike was returned with damage or if the time exceeded the three-hour maximum.<ref name="BLA" /> Implemented with an original budget of approximately £200,000, the Portsmouth ''Bikeabout'' scheme was never very successful in terms of rider usage,{{efn|The Portsmouth ''Bikeabout'' programme never exceeded 500 users at any time during its operational existence.}} in part due to the limited number of bike kiosks and hours of operation.<ref name="BLA" /><ref name="REMCO" /> Seasonal weather restrictions and concerns over unjustified charges for bike damage also imposed barriers to usage.<ref name="BLA" /> The ''Bikeabout'' program was discontinued by the University in 1998 in favour of expanded [[minibus]] service; the total costs of the ''Bikeabout'' programme were never disclosed.<ref>University of Portsmouth Academic Staff Association, Minutes of ASA Executive Meeting, 20 October 1999</ref><ref>University of Portsmouth Academic Staff Association, Meeting of ASA Executive, Annexe: presentation by Pro-Vice Chancellor Mike Bateman on mobility policy, 16 January 2002</ref> Following the discontinuation of the University of Portsmouth's ''Bikeabout'' programme in 1998<ref>[https://www.nctr.usf.edu/wp-content/uploads/2010/03/JPT-7-2-DeMaio.pdf Paul DeMaio and Jonathan Gifford "Will Smart Bikes Succeed as Public Transportation in the United States?" 'Program ended due to lack of funding'] Accessed 12 September 2017</ref> (it had been launched in 1996),<ref>[https://www.shareable.net/blog/does-bike-sharing-have-a-future Paul DeMaio: "Does Bike Sharing Have a Future?", 19 May 2010, at shareable.net] Accessed 12 September 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.smartcard.co.uk/members/newsletters/1998/nov98.pdf "Bikeabout Scheme in Portsmouth" in "Smart Card News" November 1998] Accessed 12 September 2017</ref> the introduction of new bicycle share systems proceeded more slowly in the United Kingdom than in the rest of Europe.
With initial sponsorship from [[Barclays]] and later Santander, [[Transport for London]] launched a cycle hire scheme in [[Barclays Cycle Hire|London]], where hire under 30 minutes is free from special bicycle stands across the city, after a daily, monthly or annual charge has been paid.<ref>[http://www.tfl.gov.uk/roadusers/cycling/14811.aspx What you pay | Cycling | Transport for London] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419231453/http://www.tfl.gov.uk/roadusers/cycling/14811.aspx |date=19 April 2011 }}. Tfl.gov.uk. Retrieved on 15 August 2013.</ref> [[File:Barclayscyclehire.jpg|thumb|[[Barclays Cycle Hire]], London, UK started in 2010]]
Outside of London, the largest is the hire-a-bike operation in Blackpool, operated by [[Hourbike]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hourbike.com |title=Bike Sharing UK – Bike Hire Operator – Bike Rental Schemes – Hourbike}} Accessed 12 September 2017</ref> with 60 stations and 500 bikes in the scheme. This scheme uses both RFID membership cards and instant point-of-sale memberships to cater for both residential users and the very many visitors that go to the resort every year. Hourbike also has schemes in Lincoln, Reading, Liverpool, Nottingham and Southport in England as well as Dumfries, Scotland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jul/30/london-cycle-scheme-boris-johnson|title=London cycle scheme could spread across UK|first=Helen|last=Pidd|date=30 July 2010|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
In 2017, [[ofo]], a [[Beijing]]-based bike share company, announced plans to provide shared bike services to several British cities. In 2018, the company withdrew service to several British towns and reduced service area coverage to others as part of a global restructuring plan.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.wired.co.uk/article/ofo-bike-share-leaving-sheffield-norwich-leeds|title= Why is Ofo abandoning small UK cities? It's money, not vandalism|first=Richard|last=Priday|date=24 July 2018|website=Wired}}</ref>
In May 2017, Bristol became the first European city to have a hire-a-bike system operated by [[YoBike]].<ref>[http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/yobikes-come-bristol-how-work-72891 Joe Smith "Yobikes have come to Bristol – how do they work and how can you get a free ride?" 24 May 2017, at bristolpost.co.uk] Accessed 1 June 2017</ref><ref>[http://365bristol.com/story/2017/05/09/%E2%80%98boris-bike%E2%80%99-style-project-to-launch-in-bristol/4572/ "‘Boris Bike’ style project to launch in Bristol", 9 May 2017, at 365bristol.com] Accessed 1 June 2017</ref>
Some bike-sharing schemes use mobile phone apps to reserve or sign out bikes. In the UK, [[OYBike]] delivered small-scale operations at 2 universities, 3 business parks, 3 London boroughs, and a private hotel chain in London until 2011. Like Munich's ''Call-a-Bike'', OYBike used mobile phone technology to log use and charge for hires and can set up hire points in as little as 10 minutes.<ref>[http://www.trustedreviews.com/news/obike-london-dockless-cycle-hire-2993709 James Laird, 17 July 2017: oBike UK Launch: What you need to know about the controversial ‘Boris Bike’ rival] at trustedreviews.com, accessed 8 April 2018</ref>
Brompton Bike Hire has 40 docks across 25 major locations in the UK, starting at £2.50 for 24 hours and is using the same hardware as [[BIXI Montréal]], members can rent a folding Brompton bike. The locations of the docks include London, Birmingham, Manchester, Bristol, Reading, Southampton and Oxford.<ref name="Brompton bike docks">{{cite web|url=https://www.bromptonbikehire.com/docks |title=Our Docks |website=Brompton Bike Hire|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
in 2007,<ref>[http://www.londonlovesbusiness.com/business-news/politics/exclusive-four-great-things-boris-johnson-did-that-ken-livingstone-should-get-credit-for/11839.article Robyn Vinter: "EXCLUSIVE: Four great things Boris Johnson did that Ken Livingstone should get credit for" 10 February 2016, londonlovesbusiness.com] Accessed 12 September 2017</ref> (another source gives early 2008) London mayor [[Ken Livingstone]] promised that an extensive bicycle sharing system modelled on the Paris [[Vélib']] system would be introduced in London during his final term in office.<ref name="Kenscycleways">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/feb/09/transport.world1 |title=City's two-wheel transformation|last=Taylor|first=Matthew|date=9 February 2008|work=The Guardian |location=London|accessdate=11 August 2010}}</ref> The scheme was not completed until [[Boris Johnson]] was in office, and consequently became known informally as "Boris Bikes".<ref>[http://www.theecologist.org/News/news_analysis/1337944/london_mayor_election_who_is_the_greenest_choice.html "Boris bikes and cycling in London" in "London mayor election: who is the greenest choice?" Mark Briggs 26 April 2012, at theecologist.org] Accessed 12 September 2017</ref>
In 2018 the Singaporean-based company [[oBike]] launched in [[London]], with 400 dockless bikes and is anticipated to soon spread to other cities in the UK.<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite web|author=Laura Laker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/bike-blog/2017/jul/12/londons-first-dockless-hire-bike-scheme-launches |title=London's first dockless hire bike scheme launches | Environment |publisher=The Guardian |date=12 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Sean Morrison |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/boris-bike-rival-obike-launches-in-london-with-400-dockfree-cycles-for-hire-a3585781.html |title=Dockless Boris bike rival oBike launches in London with 400 cycles for hire | London Evening Standard |publisher=Standard.co.uk |date= |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> In the UK, oBike's bike hire is 50p for 30 minutes, with a £49 deposit being required.<ref name="theguardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Burgess |first=Matt |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/london-obike-dockless |title=oBike is putting thousands of bikes on the streets of London | WIRED UK |publisher=Wired.co.uk |date= |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref>
==== Northern Ireland ==== [[Belfast]] launched a public bike hire scheme on 27 April 2015. The scheme was sponsored by [[Coca-Cola HBC]] Northern Ireland and is called [[Coca-Cola Zero Belfast Bikes]]. The [[Department for Regional Development]] (DRD) provided initial capital funding for the scheme as part of their Active Travel Demonstration Projects budget. NSL is looking after the daily operation of the scheme, while [[Nextbike]] is responsible for the bikes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coca-Cola Zero Belfast Bikes Go Live|url=http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/News/News-49339.aspx|accessdate=17 June 2016|publisher=Belfast City Council|date=27 April 2016}}</ref> There are 33 docking stations with options for expansion depending on securing additional resources and council approval.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/leisure/outdoorleisurefacilities/bikesharescheme.aspx|title=Coca-Cola Zero Belfast Bikes|publisher=}} Accessed 12 September 2017</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome to Coca Cola Zero Belfast Bikes|url=http://www.belfastbikes.co.uk/en/belfast/|website=Belfast Bikes|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
==== Scotland ====
Recent expansions to cities in Scotland piggy-backing on the Commonwealth Games 2014 in Glasgow included Glasgow and Stirling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextbike.co.uk/en/glasgow|title=Glasgow – nextbike Glasgow|work=nextbike.co.uk}} Accessed 12 September 2017</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stirlingcyclehub.org/news/136-stirling-cyclists-pedal-forth-with-new-city-wide-bike-hire-scheme|title=Stirling cyclists pedal forth with new city-wide bike hire scheme – Stirling Cycle Hub|author=Amparo Echenique|work=stirlingcyclehub.org}} Accessed 12 September 2017</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextbike.co.uk/en/stirling/|title=Stirling – nextbike Stirling|work=nextbike.co.uk}} Accessed 12 September 2017</ref> Stirling's scheme was named "Pedalforth" following a competition in the community and comprises 100 bikes and 11 stations. Glasgow was provided with 400 bikes across 31 stations in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-27984471|title=BBC News – Glasgow unveils bike hire scheme at 31 city locations|work=BBC News}} Accessed 12 September 2017</ref> A system operated by JCDecaux is proposed for Edinburgh.<ref>[http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/transport/bike-hire-scheme-could-come-with-bus-shelter-deal-1-3604947 Bike hire scheme could come with bus shelter deal], Edinburgh News, 14 November 2014, Accessed 12 September 2017</ref>
==== Wales ====
Nextbike started a public bike hire scheme operating in Cardiff on 26 March 2018, with five docking stations and 50 bicycles.<ref name=BNWCardiff>[https://businessnewswales.com/worlds-most-extensive-bikeshare-operator-nextbikes-arrive-in-cardiff/ Cardiff Council, 30 March 2018: World’s Most Extensive Bikeshare Operator Nextbikes Arrive in Cardiff] at businessnewswales.com, accessed 4 April 2018</ref> The original plan had been to have the public bike hire scheme operating in Cardiff by Autumn 2017.<ref name=WOLCardiff/> The plan is still to reach 500 cycles over 50 docking stations in the city.<ref name=BNWCardiff/> It came 6 years after OYBike ended a smaller scheme (with 10 stations), following the council's withdrawal of funding in 2011.<ref name=WOLCardiff>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/cardiffs-new-bike-hire-scheme-13201489 "Cardiff's new bike hire scheme expected to be up and running by this autumn", at walesonline.co.uk] Accessed 12 September 2017</ref>
==North America==
===Canada=== [[File:Bixi St-Laurent.jpg|thumb|[[BIXI Montréal]] station]]
====Montréal, QC==== [[File:Bixi Montreal.JPG|thumb|[[BIXI Montréal|BIXI]] Montreal, Quebec, Canada]] The first widely deployed bicycle sharing system was [[BIXI Montréal]]. [[BIXI Montréal]] launched in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://spacing.ca/montreal/2009/01/31/sneak-peak-of-a-bixi-bike/|title=Sneak peek at a Bixi bike|last=Erb|first=Chris|date=31 January 2009|work=Spacing Montreal|accessdate=11 October 2018}}</ref> It has since expanded to 6200 bicycles at 540 stations,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bixi.com/en/who-we-are|title=Who we are|work=BIXI Montreal|access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref> making it by far the largest bicycle sharing system in Canada. Although initial program costs were $15 million for planning and implementation of the Bixi project, subsequent additional costs incurred in expanding the program have driven costs upwards of $23 million.<ref>CBC News, ''Montreal's Bixi rental bikes are rolling'', 12 May 2009</ref><ref>Bixi System, ''BIXI: Phase II To Begin This Summer'', 3 July 2009</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1852747_1854195_1854146,00.html |title=Best Inventions of 2008: 19. Montreal's Public Bike System |publisher=Time |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=15 January 2012}}</ref> Started in May 2009, it has expanded to over 5000 bicycles at 450 stations.<ref>{{cite news|title=50 nouvelles stations de Bixi|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/regions/Montreal/2013/03/19/005-bixi-nouvelles-stations.shtml|accessdate=9 April 2013|newspaper=Radio-Canada|date=19 March 2013}}</ref> The system was developed by [[PBSC Urban Solutions]] along with a consortium of vendors. The [[PBSC Urban Solutions|BIXI]] technology was then used in numerous bike sharing systems in North America, Europe and Australia. The Montreal system was ranked by ''Time Magazine'' as the 19th best invention of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|last=Alter |first=Lloyd |url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2008/11/montreal-bike-share-gets-new-name.php |title=Treehugger |publisher=Treehugger |date=11 November 2008 |accessdate=15 January 2012}}</ref>
====Hamilton, ON==== [[Sobi Hamilton]] launched in March 2015 with 750 bicycles at over 100 stations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Social Bicycles in Hamilton|url=https://hamilton.socialbicycles.com|website=SoBi Hamilton|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
====Ottawa, ON==== The Bixi system was implemented in June 2009 in [[Ottawa]]/[[Gatineau]] as [[Capital Bixi]]. [[Capital Bixi]] launched in 2009 as a pilot program with 100 bicycles and 10 stations. In 2012, it was expanded to 250 bicycles and 25 stations. Its owner, the [[National Capital Commission|NCC]], sold it to US-based CycleHop in April 2014 when its operator, Montreal-based [[PBSC Urban Solutions|Public Bike System Company]], [[PBSC Urban Solutions#2014 Bankruptcy|filed for bankruptcy protection in January 2014]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metronews.ca/news/ottawa/1059825/no-ottawa-bike-share-until-early-august-says-capital-bixis-new-u-s-owner/|title=No Ottawa bike share until early August, says Capital Bixi's new U.S. owner|date=9 June 2014|work=metronews.ca}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.obj.ca/Canada---World/2014-01-21/article-3584702/Bixi-bike-service-goes-bust-in-Montreal%2C-but-expected-to-operate-this-year/1|title=Bixi bike service goes bust in Montreal, but expected to operate this year|publisher=Ottawa Business Journal|date=21 January 2014|accessdate=13 December 2016}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> CycleHop renamed the service to VeloGo and replaced the fleet with all-new 'smart' bicycles, where intelligence (i.e. [[GPS tracking unit|GPS tracking]], etc.) is built into each bicycle, instead of relying on base stations, as with Bixi system. VeloGo began its service in the summer of 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/VeloGoCanada/status/616704078979072000|title=VeloGO, 'status'|work=Twitter}}</ref>
====Toronto, ON==== From 2001 to 2006, BikeShare, operated by the [[Community Bicycle Network]] (CBN) in Toronto, was for a time the most popular community bicycle sharing program in North America. BikeShare was intended to overcome some of the theft issues by requiring yearly memberships to sign out any of the 150 refurbished yellow bikes locked up at 16 hubs throughout central Toronto. At its height, over 400 members could sign out a bike from any hub for up to three days. The hubs were located at stores, cafes and community centres where the staff would volunteer their time to sign bikes out and in.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://communitybicyclenetwork.org/bikeshare |title=BikeShare page |publisher=Communitybicyclenetwork.org |accessdate=2012-01-15}}</ref> Despite steadily increasing administrative, implementation, and maintenance costs, CBN could only charge users around 20 percent of actual costs, as users were unlikely to spend more than $50 per year for a membership. Without sufficient funds in the form of private and government grants, CBN was forced to discontinue BikeShare in 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/News/article/201282 |title=''Toronto Star'' |publisher=Thestar.com |date=10 April 2007 |accessdate=2012-01-15 |first=Matthew |last=Chung}}</ref>
[[Bike Share Toronto|Bixi Toronto]] launched in 2011 with 800 bicycles at 80 stations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGreal|first1=Ryan|title=Provincial Funding to Expand Toronto Bike Share, Boost Cycling in Other Municipalities|url=https://www.raisethehammer.org/article/2648/provincial_funding_to_expand_toronto_bike_share_boost_cycling_in_other_municipalities|accessdate=17 June 2016|publisher=Raise the Hammer|date=8 July 2015}}</ref> In 2013, when [[PBSC Urban Solutions|Public Bike System Company]] acknowledged that it could not repay its $3.9 million loan to the city, the system was taken over by the Toronto Parking Authority and renamed [[Bike Share Toronto]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kuitenbrouwer|first1=Peter|title=Toronto to eat $3.9-million loan to Bixi, turn management of troubled bike program over to Portland-based firm|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/toronto/toronto-to-eat-3-9-million-loan-to-bixi-turn-management-of-troubled-bike-program-over-to-portland-based-firm|accessdate=17 June 2016|publisher=National Post|date=25 November 2013}}</ref> In 2016, the city of Toronto signed a contract with [[PBSC Urban Solutions|PBSC]] to expand their system. Its network hosts 2,750 bicycles spread among 270 stations.<ref name="Spurr">{{cite news|last1=Spurr|first1=Ben|title=Bike Share Toronto rolls into the big time with major expansion|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2016/07/05/bike-share-toronto-rolls-into-the-big-time-with-major-expansion.html|accessdate=10 February 2017|work=The Toronto Star|date=5 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www1.toronto.ca/wps/portal/contentonly?vgnextoid=af71df79b2df6410VgnVCM10000071d60f89RCRD&nrkey=25E652902FA78D588525817000509D99|title=Bike Share Toronto expansion gives Toronto residents 70 new bike stations|date=2 August 2017|publisher=City of Toronto|access-date=9 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810011712/https://www1.toronto.ca/wps/portal/contentonly?vgnextoid=af71df79b2df6410VgnVCM10000071d60f89RCRD&nrkey=25E652902FA78D588525817000509D99#|archive-date=10 August 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Bixi system was introduced in [[Toronto]] in May 2011 as [[Bike Share Toronto|Bixi Toronto]].
====Vancouver==== In 2016, [[Vancouver]] installed a bike sharing system, [[Mobi (bike share)]], operated by CycleHop Corp.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vancouversun.com/news/vancouver+eyes+bike+share+system+roll+within+months/11738540/story.html |title=Vancouver eyes bike share system roll out within months | accessed Feb. 2016 |publisher=Vancouver Sun |accessdate=2016-02-25}}</ref>
[[Mobi (bike share)]] launched in July 2016 with 1500 bicycles at 150 stations.<ref>20 July 2016 [http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/bike-share-launch-vancouver-1.3686964 CBC News] Vancouver's long-awaited bike share service launching today</ref>
==== Victoria ==== In September 2017 a dockless bike share became available in the city of [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], starting with 150 bicycles.<ref name=":1" /> The dockless bike share is operated by [https://www.ubike.cn/en/index.html U-Bicycle].
====Edmonton==== From 2005 to 2008, a largely unregulated bike sharing program was operated by the Peoples' Pedal organisation in [[Edmonton]], Alberta. The program suffered from high theft and vandalism rates, with 95% of the bikes that had been placed into service stolen or missing by 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.peoplespedal.org/ |title=The People's Pedal website |accessed 2 October 2009 |publisher=Peoplespedal.org |accessdate=2012-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103211955/http://www.peoplespedal.org/ |archivedate=3 January 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Costa Rica=== [[Cartago, Costa Rica|Cartago]] east of [[San José, Costa Rica]] started a bikeshare program.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/BicipubliCartago?fref=ts|title=Bici Públi Cartago|website=www.facebook.com|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lara S.|first1=Juan Fernando|title=Cartago alquilará bicicletas para mitigar presas y promover salud ciudadana ''(Cartago will rent bicycles to mitigate jams and promote citizen health)''|url=http://www.nacion.com/tecnologia/avances/Cartago-alquilara-bicicletas-mitigar-presas_0_1445255484.html|accessdate=17 August 2017|publisher=La Nación (Costa Rica)|date=2014-10-15}}</ref>
===Mexico=== [[File:Rental bikes at Alameda Central, Mexico City .jpg|thumb|right|[[EcoBici (Mexico City)|EcoBici]] bicycles in [[Mexico City]]]] ====Mexico City====
[[EcoBici (Mexico City)|EcoBici]] is one of the world's largest programs, with 452 stations covering a {{convert|35|sqkm|sqmi|adj=on}} area.<ref>{{cite web|title=EcoBici (Mexico City) official website|url=https://www.ecobici.cdmx.gob.mx/|accessdate=8 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/mexico-shows-delhi-the-way-in-public-bicycle-sharing/story-CHHOww6Ja1plVKUojXPN9M.html|title=Mexico shows Delhi the way in public bicycle sharing|date=8 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
In February 2010, the government of Mexico City inaugurated a new bicycle sharing network called [[EcoBici (Mexico City)|EcoBici]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ecobici.df.gob.mx/home/home.php |title=EcoBici |language=Spanish |accessdate=17 January 2011 |publisher=EcoBici |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722225046/https://www.ecobici.df.gob.mx/home/home.php |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> With distinctive red and white liveried bicycles, the network as of February 2015 consists of 444 stations with 6,500 bicycles.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=km0|url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/distrito-federal/2015/02/16/llega-ecobici-delegacion-benito-juarez|date=February 2015|title=Llega Ecobici a la delegación Benito Juárez|trans-title=Ecobici Arrives to Benito Juarez Borough|language=Spanish}}</ref> With more than 240,000 registered users, it has been argued that Ecobici is the largest bicycle-sharing program in North America.<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet Mexico City's First Bike Mayor|url=https://www.citylab.com/transportation/2017/05/meet-mexico-citys-first-bike-mayor/527109/|website=CityLab|accessdate=2 August 2017|quote=Ecobici now has around 6,500 bikes and over 240,000 registered users (which, they argue, is the largest in North America).}}</ref> The system is run by a private company, Clear Channel México, but<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bike-sharing.blogspot.com/2010/02/north-americas-newest-and-largest.html|title=North America's Newest and Largest Year-round Service Opens in México City|accessdate=17 January 2011|publisher=MetroBike}}</ref> funded by the government with an initial investment of 75 million pesos. Users of the system are required to purchase an RFID card at a cost of 400 pesos which will provide them with access to the bicycles for one year. Use of a bicycle is free for the first 45 minutes; extra charges are applied for use beyond this time limit.
====Guadalajara==== In December 2014, the government of the State of Jalisco implemented a bicycle sharing system called MiBici with 86 stations and 860 bicycles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mexico.itdp.org/noticias/arranca-mibici-la-bicicleta-publica-de-guadalajara/|title=Arranca|date=1 December 2014|publisher=}}</ref> As of October 2016, it has 236 stations with 2 thousand bicycles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informador.com.mx/jalisco/2016/689010/6/inauguran-segunda-etapa-de-mibici.htm|title=Inauguran segunda etapa de MiBici|publisher=}}</ref> This system uses the technology and the hardware of [[PBSC Urban Solutions|PBSC]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/bixi-bike-sharing-cities-1.3539443|title=Once bankrupt, Montreal's Bixi can't keep up with global demand|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}}</ref>
====Toluca==== In November 2015, the Municipality of Toluca inaugurated a bicycle sharing system called Huitzi with 26 stations and 300 bicycles, using [[PBSC Urban Solutions|PBSC]] as a provider.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversaledomex.mx/toluca/huizi-nuevo-sistema-de-renta-de-bicis-publicas-como-funciona.html|title=Huizi, nuevo sistema de renta de bicis públicas ¿Cómo funciona?| trans-title=Huizi, new public bike rental system How does it work?|first=El Universal, CompaÃ¯Â¿Â½Ã¯Â¿Â½a PeriodÃ¯Â¿Â½stica Nacional.|last=MÃ¯Â¿Â½xico|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alasimus.org/noticias/521/pbsc-urban-solutions-lanzo-el-huizi-toluca-el-nuevo-servicio-de-alquiler-de-bicis/|title=PBSC Urban Solutions lanzó el Huizi Toluca, el nuevo servicio de alquiler de bicis| trans-title=PBSC Urban Solutions launched the Huizi Toluca, the new bike rental service|website=alasimus.org|language=es-es|access-date=2017-03-14}}</ref>
====Pachuca==== In February 2016, the Municipality of Pachuca inaugurated a bicycle sharing system called Bici Capital with 6 stations and 140 bicycles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.criteriohidalgo.com/noticias/hidalgo-ujul/hoy-arranca-bici-capital-en-pachuca|title=Hoy arranca Bici Capital en Pachuca| trans-title=Today Bici Capital starts in Pachuca|publisher=}}</ref>
====Puebla==== From January 2017, the Puebla will have a system called Bici Puebla with 139 stations and 2,100 bicycles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://intoleranciadiario.com/detalle_noticia/150413/ciudad/colocan-cicloestaciones-en-el-primer-cuadro-de-la-angelopolis|title=Colocan cicloestaciones en el primer cuadro de la Angelópolis| trans-title=They place cycle stations in the first quarter of Angelópolis|publisher=intoleranciadiario.com}}</ref>

web|url=http://greatergreaterwashington.org/post/25761/here-are-americas-largest-bikesharing-systems-as-of-2014/|title=Here are America's largest bikesharing systems as of China|url=https://mashable.com/2018/05/18/bike-to-work-dockless-bike-share/|website=Mashable|accessdate=21 May 2018|language=en}}</ref> Dallas reportedly had 20,000 bikes on the streets,<ref
