[[File:Sultan Mohamoud Ali Shire 2.jpg|thumb|[[Mohamoud Ali Shire]], ''Suldaan'' ([[Sultan]]) of the [[Warsangali Sultanate]].]] This is a list of '''Somali aristocratic and court titles''' that were historically used by the [[Somali people]]'s various [[sultan]]ates, [[Realm|kingdoms]] and [[empire]]s. Also included are the [[honorific]]s reserved for [[Islam]]ic notables as well as traditional leaders and officials within the Somali [[customary law]] (''[[xeer]]''), in addition to the [[nobiliary particle]]s set aside for distinguished individuals.
==Monarchs and aristocrats== Below is a list of the [[Court (royal)|royal court]] [[Royal and noble ranks|titles]] historically retained by the Somali [[Monarchy|monarchies]] and [[Aristocracy|aristocracies]].
===Male titles===
====Kings or Rulers ==== [[File:Sultan Ali Yusuf Kenadid.jpg|thumb|''Suldaan'' [[Ali Yusuf Kenadid]] of the [[Sultanate of Hobyo]].]] * '''Suldaan''': From the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] for [[Sultan]] or English "Chief". Very common title for rulers in the pre-colonial and colonial periods; used throughout the Somali territories, particularly by the [[Isaaq]].<ref name="Lewis203204" /> Famous Sultans include Fakr ad-Din, the first Sultan of the [[Sultanate of Mogadishu]], who built the 13th-century [[Fakr ad-Din Mosque]]; [[Nur Ahmed Aman]], Sultan of the [[Habr Yunis]] and one of the founders of the [[Dervish state]] <ref>Correspondence respecting the Rising of Mullah Muhammed Abdullah in Somaliland, and consequent military operations, 1899–1901</ref> [[Mohamoud Ali Shire]], the 26th Sultan of the [[Warsangali Sultanate]]; [[Mahmud IV]], who reigned in the early 19th century as one of the first Sultans of the Majeerteen Sultanate; [[Yusuf Ali Kenadid]], founder of the [[Sultanate of Hobyo]]; and [[Ibrahim Adeer]], founder of the [[Sultanate of Geledi|Geledi Sultanate]]. The title was also employed by the leaders of the influential [[Ajuran Sultanate]], the House of Garen. [[File:Sultan Abdillahi Sultan Deria.jpg|thumb|Portrait of Sultan Abdillahi Sultan Deria, the grand Sultan of [[Isaaq]] clans.]] * '''Ughaz''': Authentic Somali term for "Sultan". Used throughout the northern and western Somali territories; particularly in the Somali region of Ethiopia and the far northwestern area of the Somali penunsila, but also in central Somalia and southern Somalia.<ref name="Lewis203204" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yoMBQCr4LysC|title=A Pastoral Democracy: A Study of Pastoralism and Politics Among the Northern Somali of the Horn of Africa|last=Lewis|first=I. M.|date=1961-01-01|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|year=|isbn=9783825830847|location=|pages=204|language=en|via=}}</ref> The [[Gadabuursi]] in particular is the only clan with a longstanding tradition of Sultan. The Gadabursi gave their sultan the title of "Ughaz".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nlIqAQAAIAAJ|title=Africa|last=Westermann|first=Diedrich|last2=Smith|first2=Edwin William|last3=Forde|first3=Cyril Daryll|date=2007-01-01|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=|location=|page=230|pages=|language=en|via=}}</ref> *'''Boqor''': Literally denotes [[King]].<ref name="Orwin">{{cite book|last=Orwin|first=Martin|title=Aspects of Somali phonology|year=1990|publisher=University of London|pages=55}}</ref> However, in practice, it is the ''[[primus inter pares]]'' or "King of Kings".<ref name="Lewis208">{{harvcoltxt|Lewis|1999|p=208}}</ref> The title is etymologically derived from one of the [[Afro-Asiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]] [[Somali language]] terms for "belt", in recognition of the official's unifying role within society.<ref name="Lewis203204">{{harvcoltxt|Lewis|1999|pp=203–204}}</ref> According to Kobishchanow (1987), ''Boqor'' is also related to the [[Style (manner of address)|style]] ''Paqar'', which was employed by rulers in the early [[Nile Valley]] state of [[Meroe]].<ref name="Claessen">{{cite book|last=Claessen|first=H. J. M.|title=Early State Dynamics, Volume 2 of Studies in Human Society|year=1987|publisher=Brill Archive|isbn=9004081011|pages=121|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=afYUAAAAIAAJ}}</ref> Various Somali [[honorific]]s and designations have ''Boqor'' as their root. The latter include ''Boqortooyo'', signifying "monarchy", "kingdom" or "empire"; ''Boqornimo'', meaning "[[Royal family|royalty]]", "[[nobility]]" or "dignitaries";<ref name="Maxamed">{{cite book|last=Maxamed|first=Maxamed Cabdi|title=Lexique somali-français|year=1987|publisher=s.n.|pages=27|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5c8XAQAAIAAJ}}</ref> and ''Boqortinnimo'', denoting "kingship".<ref name="Zorcissa">{{cite book|last=R. David Paul Zorc|first=Abdullahi A. Issa|title=Somali Textbook|year=1990|publisher=Dunwoody Press|isbn=0931745489|pages=551|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IRkOAAAAYAAJ}}</ref> Historically, the title was mainly used by [[Monarch|rulers]] in the northeastern [[Puntland]] region of [[Somalia]].<ref name="Lewis203204" /> The most prominent Boqor in recent times was [[Osman Mahamuud]], who governed the [[Majeerteen Sultanate]] (Majeerteenia) during its 19th-century heyday. Also used among the [[Gadabuursi]] as the law of the King and the 100 men' (heerka boqorka iyo boqolka nin).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yoMBQCr4LysC&pg=PA207&lpg=PA207&dq=heerka+boqorka+iyo&source=bl&ots=927Pu93FUm&sig=_Ox8H5f3o15kKe4YcHpK8wuMbog&hl=en&sa=X&sqi=2&ved=0ahUKEwi75KjsmLPPAhUIBMAKHc_fB98Q6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=heerka%2520boqorka%2520iyo&f=false|title=A Pastoral Democracy: A Study of Pastoralism and Politics Among the Northern Somali of the Horn of Africa|last=Lewis|first=I. M.|date=1961-01-01|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|year=|isbn=9783825830847|location=|pages=207|language=en|via=}}</ref> *'''Gerad'''/'''Garad''': Often employed interchangeably with "Suldaan" to denote a Sultan. Etymologically signifies "wisdom", "mind" or "understanding". According to Basset (1952), the title corresponds with the honorific ''Al-Jaraad'', which was used during the Middle Ages by [[Muslim]] governors in the [[Islam]]ic parts of [[Ethiopia]]. ''Gerad'' was historically employed throughout northern Somalia.<ref name="Lewis203204" /> Notable Gerads include [[Gerad Dhidhin]], the founder of the Warsangali Sultanate,<ref name="Warsult">{{cite web|title=Warsangeli Sultanate - Official website|url=http://www.warsangeli.org/|publisher=ECOTERRA Intl.|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref> and Gerad Lado, who built the sturdy wall around the ancient northern port city of [[Zeila]].<ref name="Pankhurst2">{{cite book|last=Pankhurst|first=Richard|title=History of Ethiopian towns from the Middle Ages to the early nineteenth century|year=1982|publisher=Steiner|isbn=3515032045|pages=63}}</ref> *'''[[Imam]]''': Denotes the Head of State.<ref>Mohamed Haji Muktar, ''Historical Dictionary of Somalia'', (Scarecrow Press: 2003), p.35</ref> Style was used especially by rulers in the [[Adal Sultanate|Sultanate of Adal]] and the Ajuran Sultanate. Notable Imams include [[Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi]], also known as Ahmed Gurey or Gran (both meaning "the Left Handed"), who led a military campaign during the Middle Ages known as the [[Abyssinian–Adal war|Conquest of Abyssinia]] (''Futuh al-Habash''). *'''[[Emir]]''': Used by leaders in the Adal Sultanate. Also employed by commanders in the Ajuran Sultanate's [[Ajuran Sultanate#Military|armed forces and navy]]. Prominent Emirs include [[Nur ibn Mujahid]], the Emir of [[Harar]] who built the great wall (''Jugol'') around the city.
====Royal family==== *'''Amir''': [[Prince]]. Honorific set aside for the hereditary son of the King or Sultan.<ref name="Hashi">{{cite book|last=Hashi|first=Awil Ali|title=Essential English-Somali Dictionary|year=1993|publisher=Fiqi Press Ltd.|isbn=0969768508|pages=318}}</ref> Notable Princes include [[Ali Yusuf Kenadid]], the son and heir of Sultan Yusuf Ali Kenadid of the Sultanate of Hobyo. *'''Ina Boqor''': Alternate court style for the Prince.<ref name="Hashi"/> A term used by [[Ajuran Empire]] and a powerful Ajuran princess called [[Faduma Sarjelle]]
====Court officials==== [[File:Abadir Omar Al-Rida.jpg|thumb|''Sheikh'' [[Abadir Umar Ar-Rida]], patron saint in the [[Harar]] sultanate.]] *'''[[Vizier|Wazir]]''': [[Minister (government)|Minister]] and/or tax and revenue collector. Title used in the northern Majeerteen Sultanate and Sultanate of Hobyo, as well as the southern Ajuran Sultanate. Wazirs were also quite common at the royal court of the medieval Sultanate of Mogadishu. When the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] traveller [[Ibn Battuta]] visited [[Mogadishu]] in 1331, he indicated that the city was ruled by a Somali Sultan originally from the northern [[Barbara (region)|Barbara]] region, who had a retinue of wazirs, legal experts, commanders, royal [[eunuch]]s, and other officials at his service.<ref name="Laitin15">{{harvcoltxt|Laitin|Samatar|1987|p=15}}</ref> Other notable wazirs include the maternal grandfather of the Somali General [[Abdullahi Ahmed Irro]], who was part of the Sultanate of Hobyo's aristocratic contingent in the southern town of [[Kismayo]].<ref name="Hosmp">{{cite web|last=Ahmed III|first=Abdul|title=History of Somali Military Personnel|publisher=THOAPI|accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> *'''Boqortiishe''': [[Viceroy]].<ref name="Maxamed"/> Style reserved for court officials governing territory on behalf of their Kingdom was mostly used by [[Ajuran Empire]] that established many colonies and a famous ruler was [[Abd al-Aziz of Mogadishu]] who ruled [[Maldive]] islands on behalf of [[Ajuran Empire]] *'''Wakiil-Boqor''': Alternate court title designating a Viceroy.<ref name="Hashi3">{{cite book|last=Hashi|first=Awil Ali|title=Essential English-Somali Dictionary|year=1993|publisher=Fiqi Press Ltd.|isbn=0969768508|pages=442}}</ref> *'''[[Na'ib]]'''/'''Naïb''': [[Steward (office)|Deputy]] or representative of the Sultan. Duties included the administration of [[tribute]], which was collected by court soldiers. Style was used in the Ajuran Sultanate, Majeerteen Sultanate and Sultanate of Hobyo.<ref name="Cali">{{cite book|last=Axmed Faarax Cali|first=Francesco Antinucci, ed.|title=Poesia orale somala: storia di una nazione|year=1986|publisher=Ministero degli Affari Esteri, Dipartimento per la Cooperazione allo Sviluppo, Comitato Tecnico Linguistico per l'Universita Nazionale Somala|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9skXAQAAIAAJ}}</ref> *'''[[Qadi]]''': Denotes a [[Chief Judge]]. Especially common title in northern Somalia, but also used in the southern Ajuran Sultanate. Prominent Qadis include [[Abd al Aziz al-Amawi]], an influential 19th-century diplomat, historian, poet, jurist and scholar who was appointed Qadi of the [[Kilwa Sultanate]] at the age of 18 by [[Muscat and Oman]]'s Sultan [[Said bin Sultan, Sultan of Muscat and Oman|Said bin Sultan]]; and the father of Sheikh [[Abdurahman Sheikh Nuur]], inventor of the [[Borama alphabet|Borama script]] for the Somali language.<ref name="Laitin8687">{{harvcoltxt|Laitin|1977|pp=86–87}}</ref>
===Female titles===
====Consorts==== *'''Boqorad''': Literally translates as "Queen". Title mainly reserved for the [[queen consort]] of the King (''Boqor'').<ref name="Sitls">{{cite journal|publisher=University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Dept. of Linguistics|last=Kraska|first=Iwona|title=From verb to clitic and nominal suffix: The Somali -e,-o nouns|journal=Studies in the Linguistic Sciences|year=1992|volume=22|pages=97|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rv9hAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref>
====Royal family==== *'''Amirad''': [[Princess]]. Honorific set aside for the hereditary daughter of the King or Sultan.<ref name="Hashi"/> *'''Ina Boqor''': Alternate court style for the Princess.<ref name="Hashi"/>
==Religious leaders== [[File:Sheikh Ali Ayanle Samatar.jpg|thumb|''Sheikh'' Ali Ayanle Samatar, a prominent Islamic leader.]] Islamic leaders within Somali society were often drawn from or elevated to the noble ranks. Below is a list of the titles most often used historically by the clergymen ([[ulama]]):
*'''[[Sheikh]]''': Honorific for senior Muslim clerics (''wadaad''). Often abbreviated to "Sh".<ref name="Ifla">{{cite book|last=IFLA Committee on Cataloguing, IFLA International Office for UBC., IFLA International Programme for UBC., IFLA UBCIM Programme|title=International cataloguing: quarterly bulletin of the IFLA Committee on Cataloguing, Volume 11|year=1987|publisher=The Committee|pages=24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4IpBAQAAIAAJ}}</ref> Famous Sheikhs include [[Abdirahman bin Isma'il al-Jabarti]], an early Muslim leader in northern Somalia; [[Abadir Umar Ar-Rida]], the patron saint of Harar; [[Abd al-Rahman al-Jabarti]], Sheikh of the [[Riwaq (arcade)|riwaq]] in [[Cairo]] who recorded the [[French campaign in Egypt and Syria|Napoleonic invasion of Egypt]]; [[Abd Al-Rahman bin Ahmad al-Zayla'i]], scholar who played a crucial role in the spread of the [[Qadiriyya]] movement in Somalia and East Africa; [[Shaykh Sufi]], 19th-century scholar, poet, reformist and astrologist who authored ''Shadjarat al-Yakim'' ("The Tree of Certitude"); [[Abdallah al-Qutbi]], polemicist, theologian and philosopher best known for his five-part ''Al-Majmu'at al-mubaraka'' ("The Blessed Collection"); and [[Muhammad Al-Sumaalee]], teacher in the [[Masjid al-Haram]] in [[Mecca]] who influenced many of the prominent Islamic scholars of today.<ref name="Fwmas">{{cite web|title=Scholars Biographies - 15th Century - Shaykh Muhammad ibn 'Abdullaah as-Sumaalee|url=http://www.fatwa-online.com/scholarsbiographies/15thcentury/assumaalee.htm|publisher=Fatwa-Online|accessdate=26 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915024556/http://www.fatwa-online.com/scholarsbiographies/15thcentury/assumaalee.htm|archivedate=15 September 2012|df=}}</ref> *'''[[Sayyid]]''': Title of high honour meaning "[[Lord]]" or "[[Master (form of address)|Master]]".<ref name="Ifla"/> Denotes males accepted as descendants of the [[Islamic prophet]] [[Muhammad]] through his grandsons, [[Hasan ibn Ali]] and [[Hussein ibn Ali]], sons of the prophet's daughter [[Fatima Zahra]] and his son-in-law [[Ali ibn Abi Talib]].<ref name="Engseng">Ho, Engseng, ''Graves of Tarim'', (University of California Press: 2006), Berkeley. p.149</ref> Used by leaders in the [[Dervish State]]; notably by [[Mohammed Abdullah Hassan]] ("Mad Mullah").<ref name="Uhlig">{{cite book|last=Uhlig|first=Siegbert|title=Encyclopaedia Aethiopica: He-N, Volume 3|year=2007|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|isbn=344705607X|pages=1045|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l4WUdKWGcYsC}}</ref> *'''[[Sharif]]''' (pl. '''Ashraaf'''<ref name="Lewis224">{{harvcoltxt|Lewis|1999|p=224}}</ref>): Historically used to distinguish descendants of Hassan 'Ali Abuu Taalib (Hasan ibn Ali).<ref name="Lewis224"/> Often reserved for early Islamic leaders such as Sharif [[Yusuf bin Ahmad al-Kawneyn|Yusuf Barkhadle]] (popularly known as ''Aw Barkhadle'' or the "Blessed Father"),<ref name="Abdullahi13">{{harvcoltxt|Abdullahi|2001|p=13}}</ref> a man described as "the most outstanding [[saint]] in northern Somalia".<ref name="Lewis102">{{harvcoltxt|Lewis|1998|p=102}}</ref> *'''[[Hajji|Haji]]''': Honorific reserved for distinguished individuals who have performed the [[hajj]], or pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca.<ref name="Ifla"/>
==Traditional leaders and officials== {{main|Xeer}} {{History of Somalia}} {{History of Djibouti}} {{History of Somaliland}}
Below is a list of the titles traditionally employed by leaders and officials within the Somali [[customary law]] or ''[[xeer]]''.
===Leaders=== *'''Islan''': Clan chief.<ref name="Diiriye">{{cite book|last=Diiriye|first=Anwar Maxamed|title=Literature of Somali onomastics & proverbs with comparison of foreign sayings|year=2006|publisher=Gobaad Communications & Press|isbn=0972661514|pages=59|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fLdtAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> Title evolved after the fragmentation in the 18th century of the great [[Harti (Darod)|Harti]] confederation that dominated the northeastern [[Horn of Africa|Horn]] region since at least the 14th century. A general process of decentralization ensued, with new leaders known as ''Islaan'' assuming at the local level some of the power that was previously solely commanded by the Sultan of Majeerteenia, the titular head of the entire confederation. Although they nominally asserted independence from the sultanate, Islaan's mainly wielded religious rather than political authority.<ref name="Cassanelli130">{{harvcoltxt|Cassanelli|1982|p=130}}</ref> *'''Malakh''': Signifies "War Leader". Historically used mainly by the [[Rahanweyn]] clan that today forms one of the largest constituencies in southern Somalia, in addition to a few sympatric clans. Usually assigned to the Herabow sub-lineage, from which two male constituents were selected to manage the group's military affairs.<ref name="Luling103">{{harvcoltxt|Luling|2002|p=103}}</ref> *'''Akil''': From the Arabic for "wise man".<ref name="Lewis203204"/> A common title for male elders, who are the traditional clan chiefs. Used in the north, particularly in the [[Somaliland]] region of Somalia.<ref name="Abdullahi140">Abdullahi, p.140</ref>
===Officials=== *'''Oday''' (pl. '''Odayal'''): Literally "elder". The most common title for [[:wikt:advisor|advisor]]s to the clan head or [[judge]]s in xeer hearings. Used throughout the Somali territories.<ref name="Adam">{{cite book | last = Adam | first = Hussein Mohamed |author2=Richard Ford | title = Mending rips in the sky: options for Somali communities in the 21st century | publisher = Red Sea Press | year = 1997 | pages = 148 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0m9yAAAAMAAJ | isbn = 1-56902-073-6}}</ref><ref name="HAblele">{{cite web|url=http://www.hiiraan.com/op2/2008/oct/back_to_somali_roots.aspx |title=Back to Somali roots |publisher=Hiiraan.com |accessdate=2009-12-20}}</ref> *'''Heer begti''' or '''Heer boggeyal''': [[Jurist]]s or legal experts in xeer.<ref name="HAblele"/><ref name=Wspsp>{{cite book|last=WSP Somali Programme|title=Rebuilding Somalia: issues and possibilities for Puntland|year=2001|publisher=HAAN Associates|isbn=1874209049|pages=69 & 84}}</ref> *'''Gurtiyal''': [[Detective]]s.<ref name="HAblele"/> *'''Garhajiyal''': [[Lawyer|Attorneys]] in xeer cases.<ref name="HAblele"/> *'''Murkhatiyal''': [[Witness]]es in official xeer proceedings.<ref name="HAblele"/> *'''Waranle''': [[Police officer]]s to enforce the customary law.<ref name=HAblele/>
==Nobiliary particles== *'''Aw''': [[Nobiliary particle]] meaning "honorable", "venerable", or simply "[[Sir]]".<ref name="Reese">{{cite book|last=Reese|first=Scott Steven|title=Patricians of the Benaadir: Islamic learning, commerce and Somali urban identity in the nineteenth century|year=1996|publisher=University of Pennsylvania|pages=179|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UeuwAAAAIAAJ}}</ref> Reserved for learned Islamic clerics,<ref name="Ifla"/> and used throughout the Somali territories. During his research in the ancient town of [[Amud]], the historian [[G.W.B. Huntingford]] noticed that whenever an old site had the prefix ''Aw'' in its name (such as the ruins of [[Aw Barre]] and [[Aw Bube]]),<ref name="Lewis90">{{harvcoltxt|Lewis|1998|p=90}}</ref> it denoted the final resting place of a local saint.<ref>G.W.B. Huntingford, "The Town of Amud, Somalia", ''Azania'', '''13''' (1978), p. 184</ref> Similarly, the ancient island of [[Aw Garweyne]] on the southeastern Benadir littoral was named for the late Sheikh 'Ismaan, whose tomb is found there.<ref name="Bader263">{{cite book|first=Christian|last=Bader|title=Mythes et légendes de la Corne de l'Afrique|year=2000|publisher=Karthala|isbn=2845860692|page=263|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=Q9XfAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> Surveys by A.T. Curle in 1934 on several of these important ruined cities recovered various [[Artifact (archaeology)|artefacts]], such as [[pottery]] and [[coin]]s, which point to a medieval period of activity at the tail end of the Sultanate of Adal's reign.<ref name="Lewis90"/> Northern Somalia in general is home to numerous such [[archaeological site]]s, with similar edifices found at [[Haylan]], [[Qa’ableh]], [[Macajilayn]], [[Booco]], [[Qombo'ul]], [[El Ayo]], [[Heis (town)|Heis]], [[Botiala]], [[Salweyn]], [[Mudun]], [[Abasa, Somalia|Abasa]], [[Maduna]] and [[Damo, Somalia|Damo]], among other areas.<ref name="Hodd">Michael Hodd, ''East African Handbook'', (Trade & Travel Publications: 1994), p.640.</ref>

{{small|''Japonya Türkleri''}}
{{small|在日トルコ人（ざいにちトルコじん）}} |population = 5,167(2017){{citation|url=https://www.e-stat.go.jp/stat-search/file-download?statInfId=000031642055&fileKind=0|title=平成29年6月度 在留外国人}} 8,152 (Registered in Turkish Embassy, 2017){{citation|url=http://tokyo.be.mfa.gov.tr/Mission/ShowInfoNote/133696|title=Japonya'daki Türk Toplumu, 3.1.2017}} |langs = [[Japanese language|Japanese]]{{·}}[[Turkish language|Turkish]] |footnotes = Population figure given is for [[Turkish nationality law|citizens of Turkey]] living in Japan. The Turkish Embassy gives a lower figure of 2,264 (2006); however, this counts only citizens who have voluntarily registered at the embassy.{{citation | url=http://www.turkey.jp/tr/konsoloslukjaptoplum.htm | title=Japonya Türk Toplumu (Turkish People of Japan) | publisher=Turkish Embassy | publication-place=Tokyo, Japan | accessdate=2007-04-13 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506111519/http://www.turkey.jp/tr/konsoloslukjaptoplum.htm | archivedate=2008-05-06 | df= }} }} '''Turks in Japan''' ({{lang-ja|在日トルコ人（ざいにちトルコじん）}}; {{lang-tr|{{italics correction|Japonya Türkleri}}}}) are [[Turkish people|Turks]] living in [[Japan]]. The term has historically included [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] (particularly [[Volga Tatar]]) [[émigré]]s and immigrants from former [[Russian Empire]] most of whom later acquired [[Turkish nationality law|Turkish citizenship]]. ==History== In the early 20th century, groups of Tatars immigrated from [[Kazan]], [[Russia]], to [[Japan]].{{citation|periodical=National Diet Library Newsletter|issue=171|date=February 2010|last=Hayashi|first=Shunsuke|title=Yapon mohbiri – the sole magazine introducing Japan to Muslim countries of the world|url=http://www.ndl.go.jp/en/publication/ndl_newsletter/171/715.html|accessdate=2010-09-07}} The community became led by the [[Bashkir people|Bashkir]] émigré [[imam]] [[Muhammed-Gabdulkhay Kurbangaliev]] who had fought on the side of the [[White movement]] in the [[Russian Civil War]], and arrived in Japan in 1924; he then set up an organisation{{#tag:ref|Known in Japanese as the {{nihongo|東京回教団|Tokyō Kaikyōdan}}|group=fn}} to bring together the Tatars living in Tokyo. Tatars in Japan founded their first [[mosque]] and school in 1935 in [[Kobe]], and another in Tokyo in 1938, with support from Kurbangaliev's organisation.{{citation | url = http://www.turkey.jp/tr/kronoloji.htm | title = Kronoloji (Chronology) | publisher = Turkish Embassy | publication-place = Tokyo, Japan | accessdate = 2007-04-13 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070518020739/http://www.turkey.jp/tr/kronoloji.htm | archivedate = 2007-05-18 | df = }} Another Tatar organisation, the Mohammedan Printing Office in Tokyo,{{#tag:ref|{{lang-tt|Tokyo'da Mätbää-i İslamiyä}}; {{lang-ja|東京回教印刷所}} (''Tōkyō Kaikyō Insatsusho'')|group=fn}} printed the first [[Qur'an]] in Japan as well as a [[Tatar language|Tatar-language]] magazine in [[İske imlâ|Arabic script]], the ''Japan Intelligencer'';{{#tag:ref|{{lang-tt|Yapon mohbiri}}|group=fn}} it continued publication until the 1940s. Most of the Tatars emigrated after [[World War II]]. Those remaining took up Turkish citizenship in the 1950s. But There are 600-2,000 Tatars in Japan.[http://www.hrono.ru/statii/2007/adutov_jap.html Представитель культурной ассоциации «Идель-Урал» считал, что количество татар в Японии в 1930-е годы могло достигать 10000 человек] {{ref-ru}}They are almost mixed.https://archive.today/20030624221109/http://islam3.hp.infoseek.co.jp/column/kurban1.htm Though the Turkish community has diminished in size, those remaining founded the Tokyo Camii and Turkish Cultural Center in 2000.{{citation|url=http://www.tokyocamii.org/publicViews/article/sayfacesit:10/language:2|title=A Brief History of the Tokyo Camii|publisher=Tokyo Camii and Turkish Cultural Center|accessdate=2010-09-07}} In the following decade, there was a new wave of migration from Turkey, mostly consisting of people from the [[Fatsa]] area.{{citation | url=http://arsiv.sabah.com.tr/2005/10/01/cp/gnc105-20050925-102.html | title=Fatsalı'nın ikinci vatanı Japonya| accessdate= 2009-02-24| date=2005-10-01| periodical=Sabah| language=Turkish}} Some Turkish citizens in Japan are ethnic Kurds.{{cite news|last=Tsumura |first=Tadashi |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/09/03/national/japans-kurds-often-limbo-despite-significant-community/#.Vi2nMStGQrd |title=Japan's Kurds often in limbo, despite significant community |newspaper=[[The Japan Times]] |date= |accessdate=2016-08-18}} In 2015 a clash took place outside the Turkish embassy in Tokyo between Kurds and Turks, it was claimed that this began when Turks and Kurds got into a quarrel after a Kurdish party flag was shown at the embassy.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/10/turks-kurds-clash-japan-turkey-elections-151025194639100.html |title=Turks and Kurds clash in Japan over Turkey elections |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2015-10-25 |accessdate=2016-08-18}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://sputniknews.com/asia/20151025/1029071175/kurds-turks-fight-in-japan.html |title=Turks Clash With Kurds in Tokyo, at Least 4 Injured (VIDEOS, PHOTOS) |website=Sputniknews.com |date=2015-10-25 |accessdate=2016-08-18}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/news/319619-turkey-embassy-kurds-clashes/ |title=Several injured in violent brawl outside Turkish embassy in Japan |website=Rt.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2015/10/25/434883/Turkey-Japan-Tokyo-Clashes-Snap-elections- |title=PressTV-Turks, Kurds clash near embassy in Japan |website=Presstv.ir |date=2015-10-25 |accessdate=2016-08-18}} == Prominent Turks (Volga Tatars) in Japan == * Osman Yusuf (a.k.a. Johnny Yuseph, 1920 - 1982): Actor * Abdul Hannan Safa (a.k.a. Roy James, 1929 - 1982): Actor, [[foreign-born Japanese|naturalised]] in 1971 * Ömer Yusuf (a.k.a. Yusef Toruko ("Yusuf the Turk"), 1930 - 2013): [[Puroresu]] referee and actor, brother of Osman Yusuf == Gallery == File:Kushimoto-toruko-ireihi1.jpg|Memorial to the Turkish victims of [[Ertuğrul (Ottoman frigate)|the sunken ship]] in Japan File:Chinatown - Turkish Ice Cream.jpg|Turks in Japan selling [[Dondurma]] File:Maraş dondurması in Kyoto.jpg|Turkish ice cream in [[Kyoto]] File:Kobe mosque01 2816.jpg|[[Kobe Mosque]] ==See also== * [[Japan-Turkey relations]] * [[Islam in Japan]] * [[Kurds in Japan]] * [[Tatars]] * [[Volga Tatars]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|group=fn}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{citation|last=Usmanova|first=Larisa|title=The Türk-Tatar diaspora in Northeast Asia: transformation of consciousness : a historical and sociological account between 1898 and the 1950s|year=2007|publisher=Rakudasha|isbn=978-4-9903822-0-9}} * {{citation|script-title=ja:在日タタール人―歴史に翻弄されたイスラーム教徒たち |trans-title=Tatars in Japan: Muslims tossed on the waves of history|author=松長 昭 [Matsunaga Akira]|publisher=東洋書店 [Тōyō Shoten]|year=2009|isbn=978-4-88595-832-8}} {{Immigration to Japan}} {{Turkish diaspora}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turks In Japan}} [[Category:Japanese people of Turkish descent|+]] [[Category:Turkish diaspora by country]] [[Category:Turkish diaspora in Asia|Japan]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Japan]] [[Category:Ethnic minorities in Japan]] [[Category:Tatar diaspora]]

'''William Healy''' (January 20, 1869 – March 15, 1963) was a British-American [[psychiatrist]] and [[criminologist]] who started the earliest American child guidance clinic, was a pioneer of [[psychoanalysis]] in the United States, and served as the American Orthopsychiatric Association's founding president.
== Early life and education == Healy was born in [[Buckinghamshire]], England on January 20, 1869. He came from a family of farmers who had resided in Farnham Commons of Beaconsfield, twenty-five miles northwest of London for generations. When he was nine, his family immigrated to the United States, finally settling in [[Chicago]] where Healy spent the remainder of his childhood.<ref name=Snodgrass>{{citation|last=Snodgrass|first=Jon|title=William Healy (1869-1963): Pioneer Child Psychiatrist and Criminologist|journal=[[Journal of the History of the Behavioral Sciences]] |year=1984 |volume=20|pages=332–339|doi=10.1002/1520-6696(198410)20:4<332::AID-JHBS2300200403>3.0.CO;2-J|pmid=6389674|issue=4}}</ref>
At fourteen, before finishing eighth grade, Healy began work as an office boy at a bank. The small bank was somewhat of a “cultural storehouse” with Shakespearean scholars, poets, and conductors for employees. Over the next ten years, Healy became head “bookkeeper” before applying to [[Harvard University|Harvard]].<ref name=Snodgrass />
Healy likely received encouragement from William Salter, leader of the Chicago Ethical Cultural Society, Harvard alumnus, and brother-in-law of [[William James]], to apply to Harvard. Healy failed the Latin portion of the Harvard required exams but was still awarded a degree and studied at [[Harvard Medical School]] for three years before returning to Chicago and completing his degree at University of Chicago’s [[Rush Medical School]] specializing in gynecology.<ref name=Snodgrass />
== Career ==
Healy began his career in 1901 as an instructor in gynecology at [[Northwestern Medical School]]. During his two year stint there, he also edited the journal ''Gynecology and Anatomy and Physiology and Pathology''. During this time his interest began to shift toward neurology, and in 1903 he took up a post as instructor of Nervous and Mental Diseases at Chicago Polyclinic. He stayed at this post until 1916, while simultaneously running a private practice in general medicine.<ref name=Snodgrass />
In 1906 and 1907, Healy studied in Vienna, Berlin, and London, and it was during this trip that he was exposed to Freud’s ''[[The Interpretation of Dreams|Interpretation of Dreams]]''. Healy became very interested in Freud’s psychoanalysis while remaining skeptical of Freud’s focus on infantile sexuality. He was a significant factor in bringing psychoanalysis to the United States, and published ''Structure and Meaning of Psychoanalysis'' in 1931.<ref name=Snodgrass />
At a 1908 meeting at the Hull House, which Healy had been involved with since medical school, he organized a research program with juvenile delinquents in the juvenile court system. Healy traveled the country discussing his ideas, and in 1909 led the formation of the Chicago Juvenile Psychopathic Institute.<ref name=Snodgrass /> This was the first child guidance clinic.<ref name=Textbook>{{citation|last=Schultz|first=Duane P., and Sydney Ellen Schultz|title=A History of Modern Psychology|year=2012|publisher=Wadsworth, Cengage Learning|location=Belmont, CA|pages=176}}</ref> In 1917, Healy left Chicago for Boston to head the Judge Baker Foundation, a similar institution for juvenile research. Until he retired in 1947, Healy continued to conduct research at the Judge Baker Foundation, which became known as the Judge Baker Guidance Center. During this time period, he also taught periodically at Harvard, Boston College, and Yale.<ref name=Snodgrass />
== Contributions == Healy considered himself to be a psychiatrist and therapist rather than a criminologist, but he made major contributions on both sides of the spectrum. He is perhaps best known for his work in juvenile delinquency, and particularly for his creation of the first child guidance clinic. His psychiatric aims included hearing the “child’s own story” in order to create a viewpoint from the child itself rather than other sources. In criminology, he is known for supporting the multifactor theory of crime causation, which began to move the American view on crime away from the traditional European view. His work with juvenile populations led him to identify certain “causes,” as well as major and minor “factors” that appeared to contribute to delinquent behavior. However, his factors have faced criticism from others for not appearing to be truly descriptive of the populations he studied. Even Healy criticized himself for not investigating further the factors he created.<ref name=Snodgrass /> His major published work, ''The Individual Delinquent'', detailed the work that he did with factors and is considered to be his best-known work.<ref name=Snodgrass /><ref name=BrJCriminol_obit>{{citation |title=William Healy |author=P D S |journal=[[The British Journal of Criminology]] |volume=4 |pages=79–80 |jstor=/23636709 }}</ref>
==Personal life== Healy's first wife died. In 1932, he married American psychologist [[Augusta Fox Bronner]] (1881–1966), whom he had first met in 1913. Bronner was his long-term collaborator; they co-wrote multiple publications on juvenile delinquency.<ref name=Bronner_profile>{{citation |url=https://www.feministvoices.com/augusta-fox-bronner/ |author=Jacy L. Young |title=Profile: Augusta Fox Bronner |publisher= |accessdate=3 June 2018 }}</ref> Healy died in Florida in 1963.<ref name=BrJCriminol_obit />
==Selected publications== *''The Individual Delinquent'' (1915)<ref name=Snodgrass /><ref name=BrJCriminol_obit /> *''Delinquents and Criminals: Their Making and Unmaking'' (1926), with [[Augusta Bronner]]<ref name=BrJCriminol_obit /> *''New Light on Delinquency'' (1936), with Augusta Bronner<ref name=BrJCriminol_obit /> *''Roots of Crime: Psychoanalytic Studies'' (1936), with [[Franz Alexander]]<ref name=BrJCriminol_obit />

{{Infobox language |name=Yansi |nativename=''Eyansi'' |region= |states=[[DR Congo]] |ethnicity= |speakers=100,000 |date=1997 |ref=e18 |speakers2=plus 13,000 Ntsuo (2002) |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantoid languages|Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone B|Zone B]]) |fam6=some [[Yaka languages|Yaka]] (H.30)
some [[Boma–Dzing languages|Boma–Dzing]] (B.80) |dia1=Yans proper |dia2=Mbiem |dia3=Yeei |dia4=Tsong |dia5=Mpur |lc1=yns|ld1=Yansi |lc2=soo|ld2=Songo (Tsong) |guthrie=B.85 |glotto=yans1239 |glottoname=Yansi |glotto2=song1299 |glottoname2=Songo }} '''Yans''' (Yanzi) is a [[Bantu language]] spoken in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]. There are six language varieties Guthrie classified as Bantu B.85 (Yans). According to Nurse (2003), most belong to the [[Yaka language (Democratic Republic of Congo)|Yaka language]], but one or two are assigned to the [[Boma–Dzing languages]] (ex-Yanzi); he does not say which ones. Maho (2009) notes that the Tsong variety of Yansi is the unclassified "Songo" language of ''Ethnologue'' and is the one that does not belong with the rest. Ehret (2009), however, retains most varieties in B.80 and classifies only "Yanz Kimatu" as Yaka. The six Guthrie varieties are the following: *B.85A Mbiem, West Yansi *B.85B East Yans *B.85C Yeei *B.85D Tsong (Itsong, Nsong, Ntsuo, "Songo") *B.85E Mpur (Mput) *B.85F Tsambaan ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://goto.glocalnet.net/mahopapers/nuglonline.pdf Maho (2009)] *[http://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/history/ehret/kinship/BantuClassification%204-09.pdf Ehret (2009)] {{Languages of the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{Narrow Bantu languages|A-B}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Boma-Dzing languages]] [[Category:Languages of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Yaka languages]] {{Bantu-lang-stub}}

{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Zimbabweans in Botswana |total=40,000 |popplace={{hlist|[[Gaborone]]|[[Dukwe]]}} |langs={{hlist|[[English language|English]]|[[Shona language|Shona]]}} }} There is a significant population of '''Zimbabweans in Botswana'''.
==Numbers and distribution== Economic and political problems in [[Zimbabwe]] have led to significant increases in migration to [[Botswana]] since the early 2000s.<ref>{{harvnb|Campbell|Oucho|2003|p=2}}</ref> By 2003, it was estimated that there were 40,000 Zimbabwean migrants in the country, of whom only one-third were resident legally.<ref name="AfricanBusiness">{{citation|title=Botswana Countryfile: Citizens turn on Zimbabwean migrants|periodical=African Business|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Citizens+turn+on+Zimbabwean+migrants.+(Countryfile:+Botswana).-a0101291137|date=2003-05-01|accessdate=2009-08-25|last=Mukumbira|first=Rodrick}}</ref> Many reside in the Ledumadumane suburb of the capital [[Gaborone]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.zimonline.co.za/Article.aspx?ArticleId=426 |periodical=ZimOnline News Agency |date=2006-11-12 |accessdate=2009-08-25 |title=Botswana hunts down illegal Zim immigrants |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827023732/http://www.zimonline.co.za/Article.aspx?ArticleId=426 |archivedate=27 August 2009 }}</ref> There is also a camp for Zimbabwean refugees at [[Dukwe]].<ref>{{harvnb|Betts|Kaytaz|2009|p=18}}</ref>
==Illegal migration== The number of undocumented Zimbabwean migrants in Botswana was estimated at between forty and one hundred thousand {{asof|2009|lc=on}}.<ref>{{harvnb|Betts|Kaytaz|2009|p=17}}</ref> In 2012, Botswana deported 17,402 Zimbabweans, while in 2013 it had already deported 22,675 in the first ten months of the year.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.africareview.com//News/Botswana-kicks-out-more-illegal-Zimbabwe-immigrants/-/979180/2087636/-/u85te2/-/index.html?relative=true|first=Kitsepele|last=Nyathi|title=Botswana kicks out more illegal Zimbabwe immigrants|work=Africa Review|date=2013-11-25|accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref>
The illegal immigration issue has produced various tensions between the governments of Botswana and Zimbabwe, with [[Paul Mangwana]] even threatening to expel all Botswana nationals from Zimbabwe in response to the alleged poor treatment which Zimbabweans face in Botswana.<ref name="AfricanBusiness"/> Botswana claims to have deported 26,717 Zimbabweans residing in the country illegally in 2002.<ref>{{citation|periodical=Associated Press|title=More than 26,000 Zimbabweans repatriated from Zimbabwe last year|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-75400394.html|date=2003-07-16|accessdate=2009-08-25}}</ref> Beginning the following year, they also began to build an [[electric fence|electrified]] [[separation barrier|fence]] along their boundary with Zimbabwe. Botswana's agricultural officials assert that the main purpose of the fence is to stop animal rather than human migration, with the aim of preventing the transmission of [[foot-and-mouth disease]], but Zimbabwe's high commissioner in [[Gaborone]] rejects this explanation, calling it an attempt to make Zimbabwe into a "Gaza Strip".<ref>{{citation|periodical=BBC News|title=Zimbabwe crisis spills over border|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3582459.stm|last=Phillips|first=Barnaby|date=2004-03-30|accessdate=2009-08-26}}</ref> One survey found a support rate of 63% for the fence.<ref>{{harvnb|Campbell|Oucho|2003|p=20}}</ref>
Human rights abuses faced by Zimbabweans in Botswana have also become the subject of a play entitled "Voice of the People", with actors from both countries.<ref>{{citation|title=Play Showcases the Plight of Zimbabean Refugees in Southern Africa |periodical=Voice of America |date=2009-01-01 |accessdate=2009-08-25 |last=Ngwenya |first=Martin |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2009-01/2009-01-01-voa27.cfm?moddate=2009-01-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827091202/http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2009-01/2009-01-01-voa27.cfm?moddate=2009-01-01 |archivedate=27 August 2009 }}</ref>
==Employment== Zimbabweans are the most numerous nationality among registered foreign workers in Botswana.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?sid=4&aid=8&dir=2009/May/Tuesday5|periodical=Mmegi|date=2009-05-05|accessdate=2009-08-26|title=Number of foreign workers go up}}</ref> More than half of Zimbabwean migrant workers are employed in [[cowboy|cow herding]] and similar agricultural occupations, while others work in construction, real estate, retail, education, health and manufacturing.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.nehandaradio.com/zimbabwe/african/botswana/herdingcattle270109.html|date=2009-01-27|accessdate=2009-08-25|title=Most Zimbabweans in Botswana herding cattle|periodical=Nehanda Radio}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Others, especially the more-easily-exploited irregular migrants, are engaged as [[domestic worker|maid]]s or in [[sex workers|sex work]].<ref>{{harvnb|Betts|Kaytaz|2009|p=19}}</ref>
